May First, National Child Health Day By Bernice Moss HE health of the child is the power of the nation." This 1939 slogan for National Child Health Day on May first, so proclaimed each year by the President of the United States, challenges all citizens to serious consideration which will result in a fitting observance of this day. May first gives us an opportunity to seriously evaluate the health programs which we as individuals, families and communities sponsor in the interest of the child, and to call to the attention of all the needs for further effort. We should ask ourselves many questions: Are the children in our community properly fed, housed, and protected? Are mothers and infants provided with medical and nursing care? Is communicable disease _ controlled through immunization and isolation programs? Are we making adequate provision for handicapped children? Do we supply pure milk, pure water, and pure food to our people? Are there adequate playgrounds and effective recreation programs for our children? Is our home conducive to the best development of the child? Are we. Helping each child to attain his most wholesome physical, mental, social, and spiritual development? We should ask ourselves these questions and many more, and on the basis of such serious evaluation plan a program of improvement for our homes and communities. This year the responsibility for organizing the observance of May Day—Child Health Day in the State of Utah—was delegated to the Relief Society by the State Board of Health. A state-wide committee was organized under the leadership of Marcia K. Howells, general chairman. This committee represented the organizations, societies, and state departments most concerned with child health problems. The general committee drew up plans and suggestions concerning fitting observance of Child Health Day and sent them to hundreds of interested persons. A week of observance, rather than one day, was suggested, and all groups invited to participate in effective community programs under the leadership of the local Relief Societies. Programs naturally vary with communities. Some of the following methods have proved and are proving effective: church meetings devoted to health, public lectures, public forums, radio programs, newspaper articles, moving pictures, school activities including May Day festivals, health parades, assembly programs, plays, pageants, etc., demonstrations, window exhibits, community surveys to determine needs and plan programs. Such a concerted attack on the problem of child health is bound to result in an awakened consciousness on the part of our citizenry. When this consciousness is translated into effective planning and effective action in our homes, schools, and communities, we will have marched far toward the achievement of our goal. Calling All Remnant Fans By Kathleen B. Nelson AT the remnant counter Serena stood, a neatly dressed woman with a happy, thoughtful face. The silvery wave of hair against the soft rose accent on her smart little hat looked like an award of merit. Her eyes were meditative, her mouth relaxed in pleasant contemplation, as she surveyed the fabrics spread before her. She did not paw them over. Her eyes did the probing. After a careful summing up, she removed her gloves thoughtfully and reached for just the piece she wanted. She noted the price, the amount; her fingers caressed its softness; her eyes dilated over its color; her mind said, '"Marie will be lovely in a blue dress. I'll make it plain, with good lines—just a girdle of rose-buds and perhaps a handful scattered on the skirt." She laid the piece over her left arm. Another moment's contemplation. Then she picked up a picce of soft, pink flannel, this time a bit uncertainly. Suddenly her imagination made of it a baby blanket, and it, too, took its place on the left arm. "My crochet hook and some white yarn will turn that trick," she thought triumphantly. Suddenly her eyes popped and, as she held up a piece of rosy eiderdown, unreserved pleasure was written on her face. "Just big enough for a bathrobe for Teena. Won't she love it? I'll finish the edges with white yarn, too, and make a cord and tassles and embroider a white duck on the pocket." Next it was an ungainly bulk of silkaline her fingers caressed. "I'll cover my worn blankets and make a quilt for Mrs. Casoli. With that big family she can use it." At irregular intervals she made fresh discoveries until both arms were well upholstered with them. The girl at the counter was either a discerning person or else she was held fast' and speechless in an enchantment of the 'older woman's weaving. Not once did the girl disturb Serena's fruitful reverie by lifting her finger or raising her voice. A sigh of satisfaction as Serena contemplated her quarry; a smile at the girl as signal that the hunt was over, broke the spell so that she could make the required motions with her pencil and sales pad. On paper the sale might have been in code for all the secrets that it held. 1 Rem. 2.20 1 Rem,...60 1 Rem .85 1 Rem, 1.60 etc. Serena, taking it to recheck, read it thus: Dress for Marie Baby blanket for Margaret Bath robe for Teena Quilt for Mrs, Casoli Breakfast set for the girl at Simpson's Nightgown for Jennie New pillows for Ted's room Two blouses "Charge or cash?" the salesgirl intoned. "Oh, I'll pay for them." Serena presented a check. It was from her son in New York, enclosed with a note: "Please, Mother dear, buy something that you want—something that will make you happy." If he had seen her face as she took her treasure from the clerk, he would have known she had followed his instructions to the letter. The Body's Need For Vitamins By Dr. Rose H. Widtsoe, Home Economics Department, University of Utah The unique role of vitamins in general, and the specific functions of vitamin A were reviewed in the preceding article. The present article will consider vitamin B. VITAMIN B OR THIAMIN Investigation OR centuries the disease, now known as beriberi, was prevalent in the Orient before it became generally known in our Western civilization. Beriberi had attracted world attention when in 1878-1883 'Takaki, a medical officer of the Japanese navy, became convinced that the disease was not due to infection but to a nutritional deficiency. At this time the entire Japanese navy numbered 5,000 men, and out of this number 1,000 to 2,000 Or 20 to 40 per cent were sick each year with this disease. Takaki succeeded in changing the navy ration and practically irradicated the disease, but he was unable to give any explanation of the astonishing effect of the changed diet. We now know that the new diet contained vitamin B. Research followed rapidly in an attempt to discover the substance or substances responsible for such dramatic effects. It was soon determined that this "unknown substance" was an organic material appearing naturally in certain foods as well as in the water in which these foods were soaked or cooked. Finally in 1936 the chemical nature of this substance was determined. Now it can be synthesized and appears on the market in various forms. FUNCTIONS OF VITAMIN B IN NUTRITION Vitamin B Prevents the Disease Beriberi Beriberi is a disease that effects the nervous system. There are two forms of this disease, the dry and the wet. In dry beriben there is a great wasting of the muscle tissue, loss of sensation in the skin and fi nally paralysis of the nerves beginning in the legs and gradually extending to the upper portions of the body. In wet beriberi fluids collect in the tissues of the arms, legs and finally in the trunk. The heart enlarges greatly and death results from heart failure. This disease develops slowly in human beings living on a diet low in vitamin B, but a diet completely lacking in it will produce the disease rapidly. This disease can be cured with dramatic rapidity through the administration of vitamin B. The experimental animals respond to this treatment in a few hours and are completely recovered in a few days. In human beings the recovery is slower but still very dramatic. Vitamin B treatment of severe infantile beriberi is described as "almost miraculous". The most marked effect of the administration of vitamin B is its effect on the heart, which quickly returns to its normal size. Beriberi often follows cases of prolonged fevers where the effects of a diet deficient in vitamin B are more striking. Maintenance of Appetite Much that has been learned concerning the vitamins has been through animal experimentation. The vitamin B deficiency disease in animals is called polyneuritis. Very often young experimental animals on a deficient vitamin B diet will die before they develop symptoms of the nerve disease. Older animals will live for a much longer time and will show marked symptoms of the disease. 'The experimental animals soon lose their appetite. Upon the administration of vitamin B, the appetite quickly returns and the animals become normal. Doctors often find this disease in mild forms in children's wards in hospitals, the most common symptom being lack of appetite. Dr. B. R. Hoobler' of Detroit has observed that "when about one-half teaspoon of brewer's yeast concentrate was given daily to infants suspected of receiving an insufficient amount of B the appetite increased and a certain type of stiffness in the arms, legs and neck disappeared." He cites an example of one infant given this treatment that "changed from a thin, pale, spastic, restless, whining infant, refusing part of its formula, to a happy, rosy-cheeked, smiling baby whose appetite seemed never to be com- *Dr. B. R. Hoobler, Detroit: Syinptomatology of Vitamin B Deficiency in Infants, Hour. Amer. Med. Assoc., Vol. 73 (1922). RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY 301 completely satisfied, and whose gain in weight was remarkable." Effect Upon Digestion The gastro-intestinal tract (the stomach and the intestines) very soon show disturbances in the digestion, absorption and assimilation of food on a deficiency B diet. The muscles of these organs lose their tone so that the movement of food in the stomach and along the intestinal tract is slowed up. Also the vitality of the mucous lining of these organs is reduced so that there is less resistance against infection. Studies" made on human _ beings suffering with chronic arthritis—a disease in which digestion is often impaired — showed that patients "who had very greatly relaxed and sluggish intestinal tracts, made remarkable improvement when large doses of vitamin B in the form of yeast concentrate or wheat germ were administered." It has been observed in many cases in which people are really not ill, but who are always taking something to relieve a "sour stomach" or a "bad taste" in the mouth and are suffering from headache and constipation, that there has been a marked clearing up of these symptoms when a sufficient amount of vitamin B was added to their diet. Vitainin B and Growth IN experimental work with both animal and human subjects, it has been proved that vitamin B is necessary for normal growth and development. White albino rats weaned "Drs. A. A. Fletcher and S. Graham at the University of 'Toronto Hospital. 302 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE at 28 days of age from a mother who has had an adequate diet, and then put on a diet adequate in every respect except vitamin B, will continue to grow for a few days until they have used up the small amount that was stored in their bodies. At this time they begin to lose weight, the spinal column becomes misshapen with a decided hump. Such animals will die in four or five weeks. If vitamin B is added to their diet before they are too far gone, they will show signs of feeling better within a few hours; they will become interested in their food, all signs of paralysis disappear, and the rapidity with which they grow is startling. White albino rats in the animal laboratory of the Home Economics Department of the University of Utah were given a vitamin B defcient diet for eight weeks at which time they weighed less than at the beginning of the experiment and' were completely paralyzed and could not stand up. They were given a few drops of milk containing yeast. In three hours they acted as if they were just waking up. Repeated doses of milk and yeast were given. The next morning these rats were walking around. In a couple of days they appeared normal and began to grow. In order to show the effect of vitamin B in the diet of infants, Dr. J. H. Dennett of New York City observed a group of babies between the ages of five and ten months who were fed on modified cow's milk plus the orange juice and cod liver oil. These babies grew slowly or ceased entirely to gain weight, "they become fretful, flabby and pale, and either lose their appetite or fail to assimilate their food properly." To determine whether or not the lack of vitamin B was the cause of the trouble the doctor fed a large number of these babies a preparation made from wheat germ and added it to the milk formula. These babies showed a remarkable change within a few months. Their appetites returned, their muscles became firm, their color was good, and their gain in weight was considerably above the average for their age. To see whether older children on a more varied diet would be benefited by more vitamin B, Dr. A. F. Morgan of the University of California, with Miss M. M. Barry, fed a group of undernourished school children between the ages of eleven and thirteen years, two rolls daily as supplements to their school lunch. The group was divided, half of them getting two rolls made with 50 per cent wheat germ, the other half receiving an equal number of rolls made entirely from white flour. The increase in weight of the wheat germ group was approximately three times that of the white rolls group. These experiments show conclusively the effects of a diet containing liberal amounts of vitamin B on growth and development. The presence of liberal amounts of vitamin B are also necessary for successful reproduction and lactation.
NATURE OF VITAMIN B
VITAMIN B is soluble in water and is widely distributed in natural foods. The richest sources are yeast and whole cereals. Vitamin B is found in the bran and germ of cereals. Among vegetables, dried beans and peas, green asparagus, sweet corn, parsnips, turnip greens, and watercress are good sources. All whole cereals, nuts and meat contain considerable amounts. Milk is not a rich source of vitamin B. Fruits are decidedly low in vitamin B content. Vitamin B is not destroyed in the ordinary processes of household cookery. Cooking at the boiling temperature, roasting or oven baking or pressure cooking for a period of time sufficient to cook any of the ordinary foods, will not destroy the vitamin B to any considerable extent. Vitamin B is readily destroyed if soda or any alkali is added to the food. The greatest loss of vitamin B values results in the mechanical preparation of foods or by throwing away the water in which foods are cooked. Often in the manufacture of foods such as cereal preparations, the outer coatings as well as the germ are removed, and with them goes the vitamin B values. Drying or freezing do not appear to affect the vitamin B values of foods. If care is used in the selection of foods containing vitamin B values, and if they are prepared for use and cooked so as to save the water soluble B, one can provide sufficient vitamin B. It will, however, be necessary to use whole cereals and nuts and use the water in which vegetables have been cooked.
VITAMIN B REQUIREMENT
Much experimental work is being done to determine the amount of vitamin B that is needed by the body. The American Medical Association suggests 50 international units daily for infants and up to 200 I. U. for adults. Since there is no evidence of harmful effect from excess vitamin B, one may safely feed more than the suggested amounts. The vitamin B requirement increases with the rate of growth and with increased energy expenditure, so all rapidly growing children and adults working hard physically should receive liberal amounts of vitamin B ranging from 300 to 600 I. U. daily.

The Shining Heart By Sibyl Spande Bowen
CHARACTERS AND Brief SYNOPSIS—3RD INSTALLMENT
FOURSQUARE, tall and gray, the Carey mansion stood on the shores of Puget Sound, towered over by the remnants of great fir forests. But its grandeur had fallen into decay now, as had its owner, "MISS BRILL" CAREY, gray-haired spinster, who made a meager living as a seamstress. Miss Brill had overdone her frail strength the day she had gone to a wealthy friend of her father's to ask for a job for her lovely young niece, red-haired NELL CAREY, who had ambitions to be an artist, but nothing to pursue them on. Her aunt was determined to provide this opportunity and in so doing, perhaps break up the girl's halfhearted engagement to FRED NAGLE, a materialistic young chicken farmer, who valued money too much to satisfy Miss Brill's more idealistic conception of what the husband of her adored Nell should be. On their way back from an early movie, Nell and Fred come upon Miss Brill beside the road, dazed and exhausted. She tells them of Nell's chance to study art. Fred is angry, but before he has a chance to voice his protests, Miss Brill has a stroke. Faced with the problem of giving up the career she has in sight, Nell promises Fred she will marry him at the end of summer if her aunt does not recover. Secretly she is aghast at the idea. Told by the doctor that the old lady's recovery is doubtful, the girl resolves to release Philander Maddox from his promise of a job and face the future at home. Old Philander Maddox shocks her by revealing that she is no relation to Miss Brill. Distressed by this news, Nell rushes out of the room, meeting at the Maddox entrance exotic, white-haired Miss Sally Delavan, who takes unusual notice of the girl. On the road home Nell passes a stranger coming from the Carey house, but is too absorbed in the new aspect of the problem of the duty she owes Miss Brill to notice him. She knows now that she, a stranger, has been taken into the heart and home of her "aunt", to whose care she must more than ever devote herself. Even if she must let Fred help her!
CHAPTER FOUR
THE morning wind blew chill off the Sound, though the sun was bright in a cloudless sky, and Nell shivered as she carried her weeding tools out to the vegetable garden behind the Alaska house. She would be warm enough, she knew, when she started annihilating quack grass. The garden had been forgotten these last few exciting days. The girl wore no hat, and the sun flashed mahogany-red lights from her lovely hair as her head nodded to the rhythm of the hoe. On the road up the slope a motor droned, stopped. Nell couldn't see the car. It was Fred, no doubt. He often drove down from Maple Hill after the morning work in the coops was done. She worked on a few minutes, then dropped the hoe, went softly through the corn up to the end of the cabin platform. A man with eyes covered by dark glasses was looking through the window into the Alaska house.
"What do you want?" Nell demanded angrily. She looked at him suspiciously. "I'll bet you are the man who nearly scared Mrs. Kelly speechless."
The man turned. He was tall and slender, and the face behind the enormous dark glasses was too pale for a healthy man. "H'm, so there is life in the old place. I'd begun to think I'd strayed into the decade before last." His voice was irritable, his mouth petulant.
Nell's gray eyes blazed. "You might have knocked at the door and found out. Or perhaps you are in the habit of looking into windows and snooping about places."
He laughed briefly. "Oh, I say! I haven't the energy to quarrel with you. I want to rent this dingus," he indicated the Alaska house, "and I want it at once."
Nell was shocked to the marrow by the mere thought. "Oh, no, it isn't for rent! Not possibly! So if that is all you want, I'll go back to my work." She started back through the corn again. The idea! Rent the Alaska house and Miss Brill would certainly have another stroke.
"Hey! You with the green smock and bad manners! Can't we talk it over? You don't even know what I'll pay," the tall man called angrily, striding after her.
Nell turned. "I said the house isn't for rent. That means it isn't for rent, in the King's English." She was so angry now her cheeks were scarlet, her hands shook. The very nerve of him!
"And why," demanded the man with equal heat, "isn't it for rent? I want the house. It's exactly what I need. I'd like to know just why it's too precious to rent." He was smilingly sarcastic now.
Nell longed to slap him hard, just once. "My grandfather built this place, just like his home in Alaska. It's filled with all sorts of relics, and he loved it better than any spot on earth. Since he died we've never used it. It's—it's sort of a shrine," Nell told him. That ought to convince him.
The man listened impatiently. "Nonsense," he said briefly, "I wouldn't eat the place. Would you mind letting me talk to the owner?"
"I can't," Nell said stubbornly, "she's ill."
The man shrugged and started for the house. Nell ran after him. He must be insane. No sane person acted like this. She was right on his heels, protesting, when he rapped on the open kitchen door.
Mary Kelly, working at the stove, saw the dark glasses and cried out, "You're that prowler! Get out of here or I'll have the law on you."
The determined intruder did not get out. "I'm sorry, madam, but I simply can't get any place with this young person here," he indicated the pursuing Nell with a wave of the hand. "All I want is to rent your cabin down by the water, although anybody would think I'd come to commit arson, at least."
Mary Kelly dried her hands. "She heard you," she said, nodding toward Miss Brill's open door, "come on in before she starts fretting."
So the three of them trooped into the invalid's room, and Nell, white with anger at this high-handedness, explained the offer to Miss Brill. When she was through, and ready to put this upstart man in his place, she was astounded to see the old lady indicate that she'd take the offer. And Nell had, perforce, to accept the money for the advance rent from this repugnant person, who bowed ironically over her hand and murmured, "Sorry, I take the decision on this round. Better luck next time."
SURELY life was hard enough right now without having a disagreeable man like this under one's very nose for three long months. "At least," said Nell to Miss Brill, "it'll pay Mary Kelly." And Miss Brill looked grimly satisfied. So that was why, Nell thought, humbled. She'd even let a stranger tramp around the Alaska house to save me worry. Impulsively she kissed the old lady's cheek and ran out of the room, flushing. They had never been demonstrative of their love, had Nell and Miss Brilliant.
She ought to like that man, Nell told herself, again at her hoe. The money was a life-saver. But she didn't. He wasn't young enough to interest her as a man. He looked all of thirty-five. And his arrogance, his supreme nerve, and his sarcastic manner! No, she did not like the new tenant of the Alaska house.
Mary Kelly's boy, who delivered Seattle papers about the countryside, whistled from the road. "Hey! I've got an extra Times today. Maybe your aunt would like it." He tossed it into the yard and rode away on his bicycle.
Nell picked up the paper and returned to the back steps. She might as well look it over before taking it in. A daily paper was a luxury the Careys did not often afford. On a back page a small item jostled the steamship arrivals for space. Nell read it and her face became radiant, as if a light had suddenly been turned on behind it. She read the item again, carefully, word for word. It seemed too wonderful to be true. An art scholarship, right in Seattle! Three of them, really—
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 307
for the first, second and the third best paintings. She had a month in which to paint a picture to enter in the contest. She would put everything that was in her into that picture; she would make it win the first prize—a year at the Marks School. And the victory would make Miss Brill better.
Excitedly, the girl ran into the kitchen and thrust the paper to Mary Kelly. "Johnny left it," she said, and stood on a chair to rummage in the high cupboard where she stored her few canvases, her tubes of precious paint.
Mrs. Kelly already had the paper open at the society section and was settled down to a few vicarious minutes with the world of greatness and fashion. "For-ever-more," she exclaimed, "Miss Sally Delavan is home from her world cruise and has"—she quoted, "'opened her palatial home on Queen Anne Hill'."
From her perch Nell looked down into the four-column pictured face of this lady with the familiar name. A lovely face framed in beautiful white hair! A face with enormous, bored gray eyes, and a peevish, lovely mouth.
"I've seen her," she said impulsively, "at the Maddoxes. Is she so important?"
"Important!" said Mary Kelly, who knew her social register. "She's the daughter of Francis X. Delavan, the big lumber man that was. And she travels the world over, like a witch was after her, that restless she is, and comes home to the big red stone house on the hill every so often when there's no place else to go. All alone she is, with all her family gone before her."
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 308
"The poor thing," said Nell, "but with all that money, and so pretty, even with white hair—"
"It wasn't always white. I remember her when it was the color of yours, and the house was full of suitors. Why say," Mary Kelly exclaimed, "she looked the very image of you yourself as a young girl. Only more flashing and snobbish, if I may say it." And the large woman compared the girl and the pictured Miss Delavan with lively interest for a moment.
But Nell had turned back to her painting materials, her picture already taking shape in her eager mind. It must be a wonderful picture, with the magic and mystery of the early-morning Sound in it. It must win for her—that year that would be balm to Miss Brill. And in the back of her mind was another thought, that here was a reprieve if she won. She needn't be married—yet. Firmly Nell smothered this ungrateful thought. "I love him. Surely I do. He's so good, so dependable. It's just that I'm too young, that I won't be happy until I've tried this thing out." She piled brushes and canvases in her arms and jumped to the floor.
"That man in black glasses, from the Alaska house I guess you might say now, is movin' in," announced Mary Kelly. "I must say he didn't lose any time."
Nell frowned, her enthusiasm dampened for the moment. That man was like black clouds in an otherwise sunny sky.

HAPPENINGS By Annie Wells Cannon
MAY—Oh the joy of a spring day when birds and flowers and all things beautiful are ours.
MRS. JOSEPH P. KENNEDY, wife of the Ambassador to Great Britain, is a true exponent of motherhood. She was especially proud when Pope Pius XII personally presented each of her nine children a rosary after the coronation.
QUEEN GERALDINE of Albania presented an heir to the throne April 5. Almost simultaneous with the joyous event the guns of Mussolini claimed the throne for Italy.
EVE CURIE, biographer of her mother, discoverer of radium, has been given an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Mills College.
ELISE B. BARB, 23, of New York, is a modern Portia, with a choice for criminal law. In her first case she appeared as counsel for a negro charged with murder.
LOUISE A. BOYD of California, first woman to be elected a member of the American Society of Photogrammetry, has been signally honored for her photograph surveys of the far north. Denmark named a part of Greenland, Boydland; Norway made her a knight of St. Olaf; France, a chevalier of the Legion of Honor.
MARY SULLIVAN, director of Police Woman's Bureau of New York City, with her courageous helpers, play their part in the Missing Persons Bureau, in the narcotics, shoplifters and pickpockets squads, also obtaining evidence against fortune tellers and others occupied in unlawful activities. Her aid is often sought by police in foreign countries.
LI YA-CHING, Chinese woman pilot, has secured money to train women pilots for an aerial ambulance corps; the Polish women are training to serve in the trenches; Albanian women have an auxiliary force to the king's army; Osa Johnson, English woman pilot, is urging the training of women pilots. Are these things ominous forecasts?
ELIZA W. SALM and co-workers from Hawaii added interest and color to the recent Relief Society conference held in Salt Lake City.
MRS. HATTIE CRITCHLOW JENSEN of Salt Lake has again entered the field of contemporary verse in the daily press. This recognition of Utah's literary women is most gratifying.
DOROTHY CANFIELD FISHER'S new novel "Seasoned Timber" is predicted to be one of the most important books of the year. "The Tree of Liberty" by Elizabeth Page is a marvelous novel of early American history, while "Through Embassy Eyes" by Martha Dodd, "Danger Signal" by Phyllis Bottome, and "The Patriot" by Pearl Buck are outstanding books of 1939.

O—EDITORIAL—O
The Spirit Penetrateth
SO engrossed are people as a general rule in the mundane affairs of life that occasions are rare indeed when souls are deeply stirred with the finer emotions, "when the spirit penetrateth men's hearts and giveth them understanding". When these occasions do come, real values rush to the fore; life takes on new meaning, its purposes seem lofty, and in our hearts are born new resolves. Such an occasion was the opening General Session of our Relief Society Conference. From the opening number, O Morn of Beauty, rendered by our glorious Relief Society Singing Mothers, to the benediction minds were not only enlightened but souls were nourished. Rich in words of wisdom, beautiful with song, abundant with spirituality, the meeting reached its climax in the simple, sincere testimony "that God lives, that He hears and answers prayers, that Jesus is the Son of the Living God" borne by a sister from a far-away island home. The aloha of our Island sisters extended by Sister Salm, President of the Oahu Stake Relief Society, to all the Relief Society sisters of the world met a responsiveness in the hearts of everyone. Truly we experienced the power of the Gospel to make us one "even as the Father and I are one". The beautifully rendered Sanctus which followed Sister Salm's testimony, the concluding words of which are "Glory be to Thy Holy name for ever and evermore" left hearts touched and eyes moist. Nowhere in the world could be found a choicer group of women than those assembled at our Conference. Privileged women are they. Enjoying the light of the Gospel, their opportunities are abundant; likewise, their responsibilities are great. Their power as a leaven in a world sorely in need can scarcely be estimated. In closing the Conference President Robison's blessings, her earnest desire for the welfare of the women of the Church, and her deep concern that they fully measure up to their opportunities and responsibilities found an answering echo in the hearts of all. With the purposes of the great Organization to which we
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 311
belong redefined and reemphasized, with our souls touched with love and the spirit of the Almighty, with the prayer and blessing of a divinely chosen and inspired leader, future accomplishments should be great; our lives should enrich, elevate and bless the lives of thousands.
President Robison is Called to Washington
THE Relief Society organization is honored in having President Louise Y. Robison invited by Secretary of Labor Frances D. Perkins to accept committee membership in a Conference on Children in a Democracy to be held at the White House, April 26, 1939. This Conference is being organized under the direction of President Roosevelt because of his conviction that a society founded upon democratic principles finds both its aim and its security in the happiness and well being of its people, and especially its children. The Conference aims to develop practical suggestions as to ways in which we in the United States may give greater security to childhood and a larger measure of opportunity to youth. President Roosevelt is to serve as Honorary Chairman of the Conference and Frances D. Perkins is to serve as Chairman. This will be a working conference. Its membership will comprise a limited number of men and women from all parts of the country whose experience prepares them for active service on committees and panels of consultants. They will be charged with the preparation of material for presentation to the Conference. The first session will be held at the White House, April 26, 1939, with morning, afternoon, and evening meetings. After a period of committee work the final conference will be held early in 1940. We are happy and proud to have President Robison's ability and interest in child welfare recognized to the extent that she has been called upon to render her services with a few other outstanding men and women of the nation.
New Series
"Woman As An Interpreter of the Faith" is the first of a series of six articles by Maude Beeley Jacobs, which will discuss Motherhood, Friendship, Service, Education and The Challenge of Today.
MORMON HANDICRAFT Highlights
ARE you acquainted with Mormon Handicraft? Do you know its worth and fully appreciate the service it can render you and your family? Not only is it establishing some fine community projects, but it is offering you quality articles beautifully and artistically made such as might be found in Bonwit Teller's, one of New York's exclusive shops, yet costing no more than machine-made things of the same quality. The committee is doing everything in its power, such as buying material at bargain prices or in wholesale lots, to reduce the price of its finished articles to the lowest possible level and still give the makers reasonable compensation for their work. Many medium and low-priced articles are now available. Just look at the hand-knit sweaters, fairly radiating a personality of refinement and style, modeled from the very latest patterns with every stitch perfect. Some are knit of llama-down in lovely new shades and fit very snugly to the waist; others are made of snow-sheen which has the appearance of very glossy ratine. These sweaters are the last word in material and classy style—just the thing for campus and sports wear. When one of our patrons saw a dainty dusty-rose model, she could not resist ordering one for her daughter. If the shop hasn't the size or color you desire, an order will procure one for you within a few days. There are sweaters for men, too—slip-ons with or without sleeves. There is a dark maroon model of knitted worsted with a cable stitch and very masculine looking, suitable for sports wear; another is made of white cashmere sport-yarn, more dressy. Any boy would be thrilled to wear such a new spring outfit to Sunday School. There are 18 expert knitters working on this project. Come and see the samples of place cards and favors. A very gifted young woman with loads of originality makes these: dainty ladies in real party dresses, pioneer women in gingham aprons and bonnets, Indian heads, flowers and many others motifs. They are different and charming. Some of them cost only five cents each; others, three for twenty-five cents or ten cents each. Whenever you want to extend your felicitations, express your gratitude, or send your love and best wishes, see if Mormon Handicraft hasn't something which will say it just the way you would like to have it said. One hand-hammered copper bowl with a sego lily etched in the center carried a message of gratitude to a friend in New York, and this is how she answered: "If you had looked everywhere and shopped in every store, Not a gift could you have found that would have pleased me more."
RELIEF SOCIETY CONFERENCE April 4 and 5, 1939 By Julia A. F. Lund
THE Annual Conference of the Relief Society was held on April 4 and 5, 1939, in Salt Lake City, Utah, with President Louise Y. Robison presiding. The following sessions were held: An Officers' Meeting, for General, Mission and Stake Officers; four Department Meetings—Social Welfare, Work and Business, Music, and Magazine; a Reception at the Newhouse Hotel, for the combined choruses of Relief Society Singing Mothers; a Reception for Stake and Mission Officers; a Presidents' Breakfast at the Lion House; and two General Sessions in the Tabernacle. The Conference was attended by enthusiastic workers from all of the one hundred twenty-seven stakes and thirteen missions. A special delegation from Hawaii, headed by the General Secretary » Oahu Relief Society Stake President, Eliza N. Salm, was also present. It was a record-breaking attendance for Relief Society Conference. The roll call showed the following representatives: 13 mission presidents, 105 stake presidents, 148 counselors, 71 secretary-treasurers, 481 board members, making a total of 817.: The music was of outstanding excellence and was furnished by the combined choruses of Relief Society Singing Mothers, under the very able leadership of Professor Wade N. Stephens, with Dr. Frank W. Asper at the great organ, and Alta B. Cassity at the piano. The organ prelude and postlude by Lily Priestly, as well as the artistic musical contributions in the departments by Jessie E. Smith and Mrs. Dilworth Walker, added to the enjoyment of the meetings. Officers ITleeting GREETINGS President Louise Y. Robison IT IS with sincere pleasure that we meet you dear sisters in conference. There is always an element of wonder in the realization that you are here—such busy women—such splendid mothers. I realize that you have planned and worked extra long hours that your dear ones will be well cared for in your absence. Your presence indicates, too, that you have prayed as well as planned—prayed for help that you 314 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE might be of greater service to our Father's children. The program arranged for this conference has been prepared with the earnest prayer that each number will be directed by the Holy Spirit, and that you will receive the special help and inspiration which you desire. You sisters are so faithful and loyal. I sometimes wonder if the "earthen vessels" spoken of by Paul, have not become almost transparent porcelain, scarcely retarding the light of the heavenly "treasure" which God, the Father, caused to shine in your hearts. It is certain that a person who uses this treasure for the benefit of others, who has a desire to vitalize the message she carries, must become more and more the personification of the truths she would interpret. We are delighted in having six of our sisters from far away, sunny Oahu Stake with us. We welcome them and hope they will feel the love and friendship which Relief Society members have for each other. There is strength in the feeling that all over the world our Relief Society women are interested in our Organization and are praying for its success. "It is always prayertime somewhere, And across the awakening continents From shore to shore, somewhere, Our prayers are rising evermore." OFFICIAL INSTRUCTIONS President Louise Y. Robison Child Health Day HE General Board solicits your cooperation in the May Day Child Health Day program. Relief Society has been asked by the State Board of Health to be tre sponsible for the program in Utah this year. We have appointed Sister Marcia K. Howells to represent us as State Chairman. In other states you may be invited to participate. The slogan, ""The health of the child is the power of the nation," is certainly a challenge to all Relief Society women to aid this cause. Relief Society Funds We are very happy to tell you that the Presiding Bishopric has made a definite ruling on Relief Society funds in reference to the Ward Budget. The Progress of the Church for February, 1939, makes clear that there is to be no change in our methed of collecting either charity funds Or annual dues, and that our Relief Society general, charity and wheat funds are not to be placed in the Budget. We request ward presidents not to hoard general or charity funds when there are legitimate needs for their use in the wards. By legitimate needs we mean such things as the health of pregnant women and the welfare of children. Interested as we are in the missionary cause, Relief Society funds are not to be used to make gifts to missionaries if a child in the ward needs milk or medical attention to help it meet life with a stronger body and would be deprived of this aid if funds were used for other purposes. Auxiliary Enlistment Census Stake Presidents! Have the auxiljary organizations in your wards taken the general Auxiliary Enlistment Census which we asked to have made last fall? The forms were sent to you at quite an expense, thinking this census would be most helpful in the Membership Drive. The Sunday School Superintendent was placed in charge of this under the direction of the bishops with all the auxiliaries assisting. Two of the organizations were to have the original and the other two the duplicate copies of the census in order to SCENE FROM RECEPTION FOR RELIEF SOCIETY MISSION AND STAKE OFFICERS check their membership. We trust that stakes have completed this survey and used the information obtained. Preparation For Missions An appeal has come to us to urge mothers to teach their sons how to take care of themselves before they go on missions. So few know how to make their own beds, to wash their clothes or do the simplest cooking. These things are necessary to the health of the missionary. Mothers are proud of their sons or daughters when called on missions, and they 316 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE can make that mission more pleasant and the missionary more useful if they do their part in preparing these fine young people for this great experience. Although Relief Society has urged Scriptural study in the home, it is surprising how many missionaries are handicapped because they know so little about the Scriptures. One mother thought she was helping her son when she made the plea that he be not called upon to pray, saying, "It would scare him to death for he has never prayed." Surely this was not a Relief Society mother! Issuing Checks We are asking again that checks issued by Relief Society be countersigned; that the President and Secretary know the amount of funds the Organization has in the bank, and that both of these sisters sign every check. Mormon Handicraft The Mormon Handicraft has developed splendidly. We are sorry it is necessary to return some articles which do not come up to our standards. Please help the sisters to have more supervision in the wonderful native ability which they possess. In order to standardize our work and to develop greater skill in handwork the General Board has called in a group of outstanding women who act as an advisory committee. We strongly advise this same procedure in the stakes and wards. Select the most capable women in your communities and meet with them at regular periods. You will be surprised and delighted with the new ideas you will receive and the enthusiasm your groups will enjoy. Deseret Industries We are happy to tell you that the Deseret Industries are doing a fine service in supplying work—with a small wage—to people who are not otherwise employed. Will you please advise people to buy from Deseret Industries rather than from installment houses. There are fine mattresses, articles of furniture and used clothing for sale. Unlike the Bishop's Store House where merchandise is obtained on a bishop's order, the Deseret Industries sell to anyone and at very modest prices. Arrangements can be made where reliable people can pay for goods purchased, by the week or month. Alcohol Education We are greatly interested in the Church campaign for alcohol education. Brother Joseph F. Mernill, who is in charge of this work, desires to know how generally the three small books dealing with this subject have been read in your homes by all members of the family. Brother Merrill has asked the Relief Society sisters to stimulate interest in this project. Weare not required to collect money for these valuable little books, but will you stake presidents please advise your ward presidents to ask the visiting teachers to familiarize themselves with this important subject and carry the information into the homes on their regular visits. Schools are excellent mediums for — teaching children and young people the harmful effects of alcohol as a beverage. Laws in many of the states provide for this important instruction. We hope the Relief Societies will sponsor the study of the laws of your respective states, and where provision is made for such instruction that you will see that it is put into effect. Popularize it by stimulating other organizations to join with you in calling upon school RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 317 RECEIVING LINE AT RECEPTION boards and school superintendents. If young people knew what alcohol does to the body, it would certainly be a great deterrent against beginning this terribly destructive habit. Expenditures of Annual Dues To clarify a misunderstanding we would like to tell you that the money for entertainments given by the General Board does not come from the annual dues. The annual dues are spent solely for the benefit of Relief Society work. Out of the annual dues we pay for the visiting teachers' books; out of the annual dues we pay for our visits to the stakes; out of the annual dues the secretary's office sends to you our instructions and helps, but please know that annual dues are not spent for any kind of party. MY dear mission presidents, stake officers and board members, I express the appreciation of the members of the General Board for your splendid leadership. We are grate. Ful for your loyalty, for your gracious kindness to us when we visit your missions and stakes. Above all we thank our Heavenly Father for your spirituality and for the unselfish service to His children. May He continue to bless you and sustain you in your wonderful work of love, I humbly pray. 318 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE SOCIAL WELFARE INSTITUTES Bishop Joseph L. Wirthlin AM happy and thrilled to have the privilege of attending this meeting. Frankly speaking, I do not know of a group of people who have in their meetings such an atmosphere of faith and of spirituality as is found in the Relief Society meetings of this great Church. In the life of your first President, Sister Emma Smith, there is exemplified the spirit of this great Organization. A short time ago I was reading of the exodus of our people from the State of Missouri to Illinois. Having had the privilege of covering some of that territory, I deeply appreciate what our people passed through during that terrible experience. They were driven out in the middle of the night by the mob, with very little notice in order to make the proper preparation. Sister Emma Smith and her family were among these people. The President of the Church was in prison; and when the mob came to her home she gathered together her small children and a few household effects, put them into a wagon, and made the journey to the site of Nauvoo. After she arrived in Nauvoo and had established herself as best she could with her family, there being no one there to help her, the brethren of the Church who were not in prison said: "Now, Sister Smith, we have left behind in Missourl many of our brothers and sisters who are not able to come to Illinois because they have no means of transportation." Sister Smith said: "Take my wagon, take my team, take anything I have; go back to Missouri and bring those people to Illinois." This good woman, in her distress, had not forgotten those who were left behind; she gladly gave of the things she had to make it possible for the Saints in Missouri to come to Illinois. Then, I think, too, of the many fine contributions of this great Organization to the Church. To me you represent the true spirit of the Good Samaritan. I am sure there is no one who ever makes a call upon a Relief Society president, be she a stake or ward president, but that the call is answered—answered to the utmost in every way that will be for the good and benefit of those who may be in need of assistance. You have a wonderful program—a program that contemplates something more than just the physical problems of our people—a program that takes into consideration the matter of health, of education, the right kind of recreation, employment, community welfare, and above everything else, spiritual welfare. You have afforded to many women in the Church, and I dare say to some outside of it, opportunities and privileges that they could never have enjoyed had it not been for the Relief Society organization. I do not suppose that you will ever know how much happiness and real joy you have brought into the homes of many of the women of this Church because of the wonderful program that you have. The Church is making some progress relative to the problems that confront us. There is no use in denying that we have problems—serious problems. Only Sunday I saw a survey made in the United States, and if I remember the figures correctly, this was what was reported: Part of the population of this great country have a month's reserves on hand in case they were thrown out of employment. Another part of the population of this great country have enough reserves in the way of cash and food to carry them for six months if they were thrown out of employment. The conclusion of the survey was, that if something should happen in this country whereby all of these people who are now on relief projects, those who have some employment, and those who have reserves from one to six months were suddenly thrown out of work, over half of the population would be dependent upon the Government or someone else for assistance. So we have a great national problem; and as a Church we have our problems. The President of the Church and his Counselors have decided that the Church should solve this problem as far as our people are concerned. Some two and a half or three years ago the great Church Welfare Program was inaugurated, the first objective being to take care of our people, the physical needs to be provided, such as fuel, clothing, and food; and that has been done in a most magnificent way. The contributions of our agricultural stakes in the way of food have been most generous. The city stakes made cash contributions and contributions of clothing. By cooperating as a great Church we have been able to reach, in a large measure, the first objective.
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 319
The second objective has been that we provide employment. It was never intended that the Church Welfare Program should become a dole, but rather an institution that would take care of our people temporarily, and then give them something to do, the right to earn their bread by the sweat of their brow. This is the objective we are struggling for, and I am sure in time we shall achieve it. In consideration of some of the problems in connection with the Church Welfare Program the Presiding Bishopric has made some studies. We have made surveys in some of our wards. We selected a ward that was fairly well-to-do and went over the list of families being assisted by the bishopric of the ward. This bishopric was issuing relief in the form of cash, which is contrary to the spirit of the Church Welfare Program. We discovered that in some instances individuals were receiving cash allowances in amounts ranging from $25 to $50 per month, and that in some cases they were also receiving assistance from other agencies. Then we asked that a survey be made of a ward in which there were many cases where people were on WPA projects, and many who were wholly dependent upon the ward. This particular ward was one that might be classified as not a well-to-do ward. We discovered that the bishop had fifty cases and that 29 of them were receiving assistance from outside agencies, either employed by WPA or receiving some assistance from outside agencies such as the County. So with these two surveys in our office, we wondered if it would not be a good thing
320 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
to inaugurate a plan whereby we could know, whereby the bishop of the ward could know, that those who are receiving assistance from the Church were receiving it because they were worthy of it, and that there would not be any duplication of assistance. With these thoughts in mind, and after considering the matter very carefully with the General Welfare Committee, it was decided that we would inaugurate a plan whereby our sisters could receive some fundamental training in social welfare work. It was decided that we would make a beginning in the Salt Lake Region. From this Region we would branch out until eventually every stake in the Church would have in its organization some sisters who would be trained along the lines of social welfare work, that they might do this work in an intelligent, systematic way, and give this information to the bishops of the wards. In the Salt Lake Region we instituted a training class under the direction of the General Presidency of the Relief Society and their Board. This class has now met possibly five or six times; and here, under the direction of Sister Amy B. Lyman and Sister Amy W. Evans and others, these sisters are being given the fundamentals that I have already mentioned to you. In making a study of their outlines I have noted two or three points which to me are most interesting and vital in this great work of understanding people and of knowing how to approach them in connection with their most intimate problems. In this outline it is contemplated first that the individual making the survey in connection with the family shall have a complete understanding of the relationship between the Relief Society and the bishop. I should like to say a word about the bishop and his position in the Church. In the ward he is the common judge in Israel; he is the presiding authority, and all projects and movements are under his direction. The auxiliary organizations of the Church, such as the Relief Society, Primary and the Mutual Improvement Association are helps and aids to him in seeing that the Church program is carried forward. No auxiliary organization ever takes precedence over the bishop, and I am sure, Sister Robison, that there is no group in the Church who understands this more thoroughly than these loyal, devoted sisters. I presided over a ward during the darkest days of the depression. Over night there was thrust upon the shoulders of the bishopric forty families, and I want to say to you, we were lost. If it had not been for the fine Relief Society president and Relief Society organization pointing out the way, I am confident we would have had many problems that would not have been solved; we leaned entirely upon the Relief Society organization. We provided the food and clothing and all the necessities. They saw that this was properly distributed. They visited families for us and brought back reports which were most helpful. So, in connection with this work you aid the bishop. You are responsible to him. And no doubt, in connection with the project I am going to present to you in a moment, he will direct your efforts and prescribe more or less the plan he wants followed in his ward. In connection with this training class, there are some fundamentals which are most pertinent to the successful carrying on of this important welfare work. First, the ability of the worker to keep strictly confidential the affairs of the people being helped. There are individuals in the Church, who because of their pride, hate to go to the bishop and confess that they are in need, but when such is the case and the bishop calls in his Relief Society president and tells her of this situation, then the obligation rests upon her to keep absolutely confidential all matters pertaining to the family involved. This is one of the most important qualifications of a worker, for a worker who cannot keep the confidence of her people soon loses her influence with them, and she will not be successful. When this call comes to your stake under the direction of the General Board, I am sure this particular phase of the work will be given special emphasis. There is the matter of good judgment. I would like to say this in connection with the needs of the people of our Church—their home needs, their physical needs—there is no one better qualified to determine what these needs are than you mothers, the managers of homes. You know more about these matters than we men, so your judgment should be good. In passing, let me read to you a statement in connection with good judgment: "The worker should be able to make plans that are practicable. She should not be overemotional, as it is a well known fact that too much emotion interferes with good judgment. Nor should she be too impulsive, but should
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 321
be able to think through a situation carefully before acting." I am sure this statement is most pertinent to the work you are called to do. There is the matter of tact. "Thoughtfulness for the feelings of others, and a kind attitude toward them is an essential element in the personality of a worker." I should like to digress here long enough to tell you a little story where the feelings of some good people were sorely hurt. There was a Priesthood quorum in the Church who knew that one of its members was in distress, and out of goodness of heart purchased fine pieces of clothing for this man and his good wife. Then with the very best of intentions, and without consulting the man or his wife, these articles of clothing were presented to them unexpectedly. It almost broke the heart of the woman. She was proud and did not know anyone knew of her condition. Had someone gone into that home and talked the matter through with them and found out what their needs were, with tact and diplomacy, no doubt these articles could have been given to them and would have been accepted with no one's feelings being hurt. The matter of thinking of the feelings of people is essential, and I am sure there is no one who can approach these problems with finer tact and diplomacy than the women of the great Relief Society Organization. Here is another point found in the outline of the General Board: "Sympathy and tolerance: Real sympathy says little but does much. To be tolerant a worker should be able to suspend judgment until all the facts are known and both sides
322 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
of the question considered—never condemn a person unheard; and she should be able to see the other's point of view." I am sure that is splendid advice. These workers should have the ability to work with others and to work under direction. As I said in the beginning, you will work under the direction of the bishop and the president of the stake. If I am not mistaken, it is the intention of the Relief Society to give this assignment of visiting families and making the survey of the ward to the Relief Society president; and should she not be able to do this work, she and the bishop should select a person ideally fitted for it. In the next place, the worker should have a real liking for the work she is called to do, and the suggestion comes that she should have good native intelligence and a wholesome personality. I am sure there is no group of women in the world who have more native intelligence than those found in Relief Society, and every woman who comes in contact with this Organization develops personality. Here is the meat of this whole outline—the important thing. Through this suggestion comes the achievement of our second objective, that people shall be taught to help and assist themselves. The Church Welfare Program is not a dole. "Put into every man's heart a sense of his own supreme worth in the sight of God"—that is the spiritual side. Respect for the individual and for his personality and character is a fundamental principle in the art of helping. It aims to maintain the self-respect of the individual—to help in such a way that he will not suffer undue humiliation. The next aim should be to maintain his morale so that he will not lose his desire for independence and allow others to do for him what he could do for himself. People must be taught, and we must encourage them to keep their independence, and not allow us or anyone else to do something for them that they can do for themselves. There is no question but that the program of the past seven or eight years relative to relief has had a demoralizing effect upon the American people, because the people have had things done for them in many instances where they could have done for themselves. In the Church Program it is our intention to see that everyone does what he can for himself, and remove from his mind and thoughts the idea that he is dependent upon someone. Any normal individual may require temporary assistance, that is true. The first objective of the Church Welfare Program was to furnish temporary assistance in the form of food and shelter and clothing, but to keep him in a state of dependence when he could maintain himself is a crime against the individual as well as the society which supports him. It robs society of the kind of people who make a self-sustaining social order possible, and causes the individual to sell his birthright for a mess of pottage. You have had contact with families who will permit you to take care of them indefinitely. They will permit you to do everything that you possibly can for them without making any effort to assist themselves. As members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints we want to go back to the fundamentals of the pioneers and teach our people, in so far as it is possible, to stand squarely upon their own feet, and to meet the issues as best they can, with the assurance that there is always someone interested in them to the extent that they will not have to go hungry. The Relief Society keeps in mind this principle in the care of the needy. Its efforts will always build up rather than destroy those qualities in personality which contribute to the welfare of the individual and through him to society. In looking over the annual report of the Relief Society for the year 1938, I find that you practice what you preach. Many people have come to the office of the General Board for assistance, and here is what you have done: 3,877 women applied for work; 3,375 employers were solicited for work, and there were 2,680 women placed in employment. That is real rehabilitation, and if we could just accomplish throughout the Church what is being accomplished in the Relief Society in this particular connection, I am sure we would preserve the independence of all our people who find themselves in need. As I said in the beginning, this matter of making investigations is a serious one that must be done in all kindness; and if, after you have made an investigation for a bishop, he refuses to follow your suggestions, do not feel hurt. You have done your duty. You have fulfilled your assignment. There is just another word in connection with finances. The finances that are used to take care of our people and the finances of the
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 323
Church Welfare Program come from the tithes. To me tithing is the most sacred money that anyone can handle. Taxes are sacred, but tithing is far more sacred because it belongs to the Lord. It represents the widow's mite, and it also represents the large income of the rich man. We must handle it most intelligently so that the dollars will go as far as possible. As time goes on, as I said, the Relief Society Board will come into your stakes and bring to you this program. It had its beginning in the Salt Lake Region composed of sixteen stakes, and I am sure it is going to produce for us some splendid results. I sincerely trust that the Lord will bless and sustain you in your great work. Your faith and loyalty to the Church are an inspiration. I met a man in the Temple grounds yesterday as this great crowd of Singing Mothers emerged from the Tabernacle. He was a stranger within our gates, and he asked, "Who are all these women?" "They are Singing Mothers of the Relief Society." He said, "It must cost the Church a great amount of money to bring them here and pay them to sing." I said, "They are not paid; they pay their own transportation, coming from the remote parts of the Church, and paying all expenses." He said, "I cannot believe it; I do not know how that can be possible." But I told him such was the case, and that they were glad to come, feeling it a privilege to serve the Church. I pray the Lord to bless and continue to inspire you in this great work.

PROGRESS OF THE 1938 MEMBERSHIP DRIVE By Rae B. Barker
ONE-FOURTH of our time for membership building has slipped by. Are we one-fourth nearer our objective? Whatever the result, it is the combined effort, successes and disappointments of all of us. The kind of report you want to hear, of course, would be one of progress. It is one of progress. There are some gratifying highlights of splendid achievement. Those ranking highest, in the order of their increase in numbers are: Western States Mission, Los Angeles, South Davis, Carbon, Blackfoot, Smithfield, Grant, Oakland, Pioneer, Tooele and Wells. From the standpoint of percentage of increase, Los Angeles and Western States Mission more than satisfied their four-year quotas. South Davis and Oakland completed their three-year quotas. However, this is not a complete picture, for the report as a whole has its hills and valleys. Those groups just mentioned reached the hill-tops; others are still climbing. Some are resting on the plateaus; others have slipped down a little into the valleys—they have lost rather than gained. The membership increase for 1937 was two thousand. Our increase for 1938 was a little above five thousand, one thousand more being needed for this year's quota. Emphasis placed on membership the past year has definitely accelerated our rate of growth. Numbers never tell the whole story. They fail to show the handicaps you struggled with in localities of varied conditions, or the splendid spirit with which you set out to do the work. Your original ideas and ingenuity would indicate that many used the old but practical formula for success, "Do what you can, where you are, with what you have." From various reports we glean the following pertinent observations: 1. Stake presidents realized that the attitude of the head spreads through the entire body. They accepted the membership assignment as an important one and entrusted the actual work to capable coordinators backed by the support of the stake board. 2. The most fruitful methods included personal contact work carried on through the cooperation of the visiting teachers and of the class leaders assisted by small special committees, all acting with the help and direction of the coordinators. 3. It was an incentive to excel when each ward coordinator knew that her individual results in the drive would be given in a suitable stake gathering. 4. Many organizations recognized big possibilities for attracting new members through the new course, Education for Family Life. In one class there are thirty women who have never belonged to Relief Society, another has twenty, and there are many others with similar numbers. Its appeal particularly to young parents has met with most favorable response. Perhaps to some stakes that have made very little increase in membership, this may suggest a new source for increase. Five thousand sisters have affiliated with us for the first time this year. Will we keep them with us? The Prophet Joseph Smith gave us a helpful clue when he said to the Nauvoo Relief Society this, in effect, if you want to lead people into new ways, take them by the hand and watch over them in tenderness. Further he said, "When any person manifests the least kindness and love to me, oh what a power it has over my mind." Perhaps we could stress a little more in our organizations bonding (cementing) through friendliness. Another thought worthy of our reflection is that all we may say to publicize Relief Society must be backed by the best organization work we are capable of doing. We
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 325
may work diligently to attract women to our meetings, but the worthwhileness of the meeting itself will be the final answer as to whether we hold those whom we attract. Do you see membership building as an opportunity to share with others the priceless thing you enjoy—do you see it as Relief Society's way of spreading the blessings of the Gospel? If we have enjoyed choice privileges because of Relief Society experiences, perhaps we should remember the Savior's words to Peter: "When thou art converted strengthen thy brother." We give our love to the five thousand new members of 1938 and extend our hands to yet other thousands during the coming year. The address "Builders In Action" by Bessie Redding will appear in a later issue.
Social Welfare Department Counselor Amy B. Lyman, Chairman
FAMILY CONSERVATION AN AIM OF THE CHURCH WELFARE DEPARTMENT Clyde C. Edmonds, General Welfare Committee
I HOPE I have a proper conception of what was expected when the subject, Family Conservation an Aim of the Church Welfare Program was assigned to me. I like to think of the Welfare Program in terms of the Lord helping those who help themselves. Sometimes I wonder whether people have lost the spirit of the faithful and a willingness to do, particularly when things stack up against them and they become discouraged. It would be a fine thing if all people had the attitude that it is all right to ask for blessings, provided they are also willing to work for these blessings. I sincerely believe we should approach our problems from the point of view that the Lord will help those who are willing to help themselves. That is another way of saying, "Charity begins at home," and is the angle from which I would like to discuss the problem. Have the necessary adjustments been made in homes where misfortune may have fallen? Have family members squared themselves to their problems? Have they taken the atti-
326 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
tude that adjustments must be made, or are they assuming that the world owes them a living? The sheriff told me that not so long ago he went into a certain section of the state to repossess an automobile. When he approached the home, he was absolutely dumbfounded. It was a two-room house, and there were five or six children. All was confusion in the home. Mattresses were strewn on the floor of one room, where all of the family slept; they were living in the other room. Yet, here was a man driving a Pierce-Arrow automobile. The sheriff said, "I must ask you why you bought such an expensive automobile." The man pointed across the fields and said, "Over there is my neighbor who has a fine automobile. My children are just as good as his and are entitled to enjoy just as fine things; during the time we had the automobile we enjoyed it." I think these people failed to recognize that in order to achieve their purposes they should have adjusted themselves to their circumstances and tried to make the condition within the home better instead of putting all they had in an automobile. I like the thought of cooperation within the family, a division of responsibility, so that everyone senses the fact that he has definite work to do, and that the harmony of the home depends upon his doing it. I believe one way out of family difficulties is through cooperation. When we discuss our problems and make them family problems, we will be able to bring about better adjustments. I think the problem of many of us is just the lack of good old thrift. When I think of what my mother did as a widow on a very meager income, I am truly ashamed that I have not achieved more. My plea is to make thrift the theme song of rehabilitation. I like the idea of a family budget. Plenty of our people do not know what we mean by a budget. It is determining how we are going to let our money be spent, and what we intend to achieve through the budget; and once we live by it, we will be surprised how well things work out. Our Church leaders have always told us to live within our means in order that we shall not be caught in a very unfavorable position. I like the idea of trying to catch a vision of the real values, the genuine values, the things that mean most to us in the final analysis. Our ideals are the things that are really worth while in life. Let us implant them in our lives and in the lives of our children and help them to appreciate the fine things that mean so much in making a rich life. I think about this a great deal when speaking about living within our means. I have two very fine friends. Both of these men at the present time are earning about the same amount of money. In one home you find system, order, convenience, with things in a reasonable state of repair. The four children are well dressed, neat and clean. The father and mother are doing their duty and measuring up to the requirements made of them in the ward. Altogether you find a very pleasing, happy environment. In the other friend's home exactly the opposite condition exists. The front door-yard reveals things as they are throughout—a poorly governed family and poor management within the home. The husband works hard and earns a reasonably adequate income, but there is poor organization somewhere—a lack of cooperation; something is wrong. These two homes have almost identical incomes, but the families are different types. There is a job to do with the one family—they should be taught home management and the value of a budget. I WONDER if there is not a general shifting of pride in the human family. In the past a great deal of time and thought was given to our homes and surroundings. We enjoyed having our friends come to see us so that they might also enjoy our very comfortable and pleasant, though often humble, surroundings. Has pride shifted from the home and its surroundings to the automobile! It would be a good thing if the shift could be turned partially back till the home and families find real pride and satisfaction in beautiful surroundings—a garden—let us even be thrifty enough to say a vegetable garden. We do not see these as often as we used to, and that is one of the things we should consider in a return to thrift. As I travel over this country, I come back to Utah chagrined over conditions I have seen in our communities as compared with what I have seen in other states. Have we failed to realize the need for a cheerful and pleasing environment? As you drive home, check up, and
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 327
you will find far more unpainted than painted homes in the large communities. Look at the fences along the highway and see if you can take pride in the surroundings. When you do find a beautifully kept place, it is like an oasis in a desert. What is the matter? Have we lost pride in our homes? Have our standards of living allowed us to sink to such a level that we do not see what is all around us? Have we become accustomed to run-down conditions in the midst of which we live? I have never been able to understand why a fence is allowed to fall down. Keeping things in repair takes a few hours, of course, but the satisfaction that comes from the improved appearance more than pays for the time spent. I cannot help but wonder if children brought up in an untidy home, growing up in careless surroundings, do not later reflect this carelessness. I urge that we devise ways and means of improving our homes, so that our children may have greater pride in them and a desire to bring their friends to the home instead of going away from it. One of the cardinal points in the Welfare Program of the Church is the raising of the standards of living. I believe we ought to keep that uppermost in our minds and influence our neighbors to make Utah communities, by which the Mormon people are judged, a little more cheerful, bright and attractive. If we can get this message over to our people I am sure we will have achieved our purpose. The addresses "What Relief Society Has Contributed To Family Welfare" by Amy W. Evans and "Problems of Modern Family Life" by Caroline M. Hendricks will appear in a later issue.

INTERPRETING HOMEMAKING THROUGH WORK AND BUSINESS By Anna S. Barlow
IT is the ambition of every Latter-day Saint woman to make her home a place where family members live together in love and harmony; a place in which they take pride; a place where their minds, souls and bodies are daily recreated for greater accomplishment. Modern life gives us an opportunity to make our homes fulfill their highest purpose—that of producing happy citizens, physically, mentally, spiritually healthy and sensitive to their social responsibilities. In assuming their tasks as homemakers mothers are more and more realizing that knowledge, training, preparation, and constant effort are essential to success. The Work and Business Department is immediately concerned with providing knowledge and training in the practical phases of homemaking. It will always be the function of the Relief Society to sew for the needy on Work and Business day, but because of urgent needs and insistent demands other programs have been inaugurated. At the present time throughout the United States people are becoming more and more conscious of the importance of proper food supplies, food habits, and regulated appetites. People are becoming more and more concerned with malnutrition of infants and children. Dorothy Thompson, famous news commentator, in a recent magazine article entitled Children Starve in This Land of Plenty said that from one-eighth to one-fifth of all children in the United States are undernourished. The course of study suggested last year by the General Board, Selection and Preparation of Food for Nutrition, has been taken up in many stakes with success. It is suggested by the General Board that for the coming year we continue this study, and it is hoped that those who have not taken the course will do so. The following subjects have been selected as a suggestive course: Year's Food Supply. Food Sanitation. Clean Dishes. Selection and Preparation of Vegetables. Efficient Kitchen for Food Preparation. Food Habits and Appetites. Safe Cleaning Suggestions. School Lunches. Preservation. ANEMIA It is suggested that the plan given last year for conducting the course be used this coming year. We refer you to the May Magazine for 1938. Material will be compiled, with lists of pamphlets included, and sent to stake presidents in the near future; these lists will also be published in the Magazine. Additional material may be published in the Magazine from time to time. It is suggested that stake Work and Business leaders contact their
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 329
own Boards of Health and agricultural colleges for additional material on these subjects. Libraries, current magazines and newspapers will be profitable sources of information. What greater objective could the Work and Business department have than that of aiding mothers in the problem of developing physically healthy family members. The address, Guarding the Family Health, by Elna Miller will appear in a later issue.
