TEN MINUTES—THEY ARE YOURS By Ida Peterson Beal
"WITHOUT practice there can be no interest, and without interest there can be no progress." Here indeed is a challenge! Our music directors must accept it. Ten minutes of the regular Relief Society meeting, except the first Tuesday of the month, have been given to choristers and organists for song practice time. Make these ten golden minutes pay a rich dividend in better singing and in a keener and deeper appreciation of our hymns and good music in general. In order to make them profitable the chorister and the organist must be united in their aims. The work for each Tuesday should be well planned. Be conversant with the songs you plan to teach. Choristers, know the words of the hymns so that you may have your eyes on the singers. Know the tempo and beat time correctly. Observe the marks of expression, emphasize them, and make them effective. Draw attention to the beauty of the words—they are sermons. Do not attempt too many songs for one practice. The organist should play the hymns without errors, giving a full rich tone so that the singers may hear the harmonies accurately. She, too, should observe carefully the marks of expression. Endeavor to have altos and sopranos well balanced. Stress proper posture and breathing—this is very essential. Never nag! Praise brings about better results. The personality of the chorister is felt by the singers. Give them the leadership they need, and the results will be very gratifying. Choristers and organists should study the Magazine carefully. A knowledge of the lesson material is important. It will give you the theme on which you base the selection of hymns for the day. Do not neglect this correlation; it has a definite place in your preparation. There is much good material in the Magazine for the instruction of music leaders. You must not fail your ward presidency. Your preparation for your ten minutes must be as painstaking and accurate as that manifested by the wide-awake class leaders. Your part is important, and in the great scheme of Relief Society you must establish the value of good music. It has been said that singing gives "tone" to the meeting. The ward presidency have confidence in your ability; do not disappoint them. Seek divine guidance, greet your opportunities and gratefully acknowledge your part in improving the glorious gift of song.
Magazine Department Belle S. Spafford, Chairman
MY CALLING By Eleanor S. Muir
I AM happy that my calling is identified with the Relief Society Magazine. I want to share the joy of its possession and its high ideals with every Latter-day Saint woman in my stake. My goal is not percentages. Percentages are useful as a barometer; they tell a story; they tell me whether or not we are a little closer to our real goal. Our real goal is to build homes by placing in them a magazine which carries vital messages every month. How can we be sure of success in our Magazine work? To me the answer is organization. As stake Magazine agents we should first plan our own program, then assist the ward agents to make plans, giving them as much help as possible in the execution of these plans. Then comes the check-up. I think success is more assured if some member of the stake board is responsible for the Magazine all of the time, rather than having the work assigned to some member during the the Drive and then letting it drift the remainder of the year. 'The Magazine work is year around work. There are many obstacles which beset the path of a Magazine representative. The greatest of these is perhaps a wrong mental attitude toward the work. If a representative approaches her work feeling that she does not care much for it and is only doing it because it is her duty, then she fails before she has started. If she has the attitude that only half the women in her ward can afford the Magazine, then without doubt her results will be disappointing. Low incomes do not necessarily mean low sales percentages, for there is a great desire for spirituality and culture among the low income groups of our Church. I consider the complete cooperation of the ward presidency of vital importance. In the Union meeting department we have dealt with such subjects as: Promotion of Good Reading, Personality in Your Work, Business-like Procedure, How to Approach People, Follow-up Work, The Need of the Magazine, Our Magazine and Its Editorial Policy, and Human Interest Back of the Magazine. The ward agents report on their work every month. Prior to launching the Drive, I hold a Pep Rally at my home with the ward agents and ward presidents. At this time I give the agents their instructions: First, the specific instructions which come from the General Board; second, the additional instructions and suggestions necessary to make our: stake Drive successful. In addition to the free subscriptions given by the General Board, the stake also gives free subscriptions and a framed award. I don't know of any magic tricks whereby the Magazine may be sold. But I do know we must be enthusiastic and energetic; we must do our work for the joy we find in it. The Magazine has no tongue but our tongues, no hands but our hands, no feet but our feet; so it is our calling to promote its circulation. 332 MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE SELLING By Edith Wilson WHEN I was called to work as Magazine agent in my ward, I felt very humble. Our percentage of subscriptions was low, and this was my first experience in selling. So before undertaking my work, I asked my Heavenly Father to bless me that I might be able to accomplish the thing which I had been called upon to do. It is very necessary to be orderly in keeping a record of subscribers. I have a book used only for this purpose. On one page are the names of those whose subscriptions begin in January, another page is for February, and so on through the year. When it is nearly time for them to renew their subscriptions I remind them—early enough for them to put away the dollar. I watch for people who move into the ward and for new members and workers in the Relief Society. I try to become acquainted with them before I call at their homes. I try to learn what their interests are. When I call at the home I try to lead the sister to talk about her interests before I mention the Magazine. Often there is some article in the Magazine that contains information on the very thing in which she is most interested. I appreciate having the visiting teachers speak of the value of the Magazine in the homes they visit. Talks given in Relief Society and Sacrament meeting are of great help also. Every non-subscriber has a reason for not taking the Magazine, so I try to prepare to meet every objection. For example, some people say, "I cannot afford to take it." I explain to them that it costs less than g cents a copy. Some of the mothers tell me they are now taking too many magazines. I tell them this magazine is different because every one in the family will enjoy reading it. I suggest leaving one of my magazines in the home, saying I will call later for it. I find I get many subscriptions this way. Where the mother is not a member of our Relief Society, and so feels she has no need of the Magazine, I explain about our Organization and also tell her about the contents of the Magazine. Here again I leave a copy. I find that if she subscribes, she usually becomes a member of our Society sooner or later, and I feel this is real missionary work. I always get in touch with new subscribers and ask them if they are receiving their magazines and if they enjoy reading them. I often suggest some interesting article to them. I never feel discouraged if I fail to get a subscription the first time I call. I manage to call again and again and find it always pays. I try to make the sisters feel that they are not just paying out money for a periodical but that the Relief Society Magazine is really a messenger, sent to their homes to deliver a real, tangible blessing in the form of good will and valuable truths from our leaders who are inspired by the Lord. The address “The Magazine a Medium For Growth" by Dorothy Clapp Robinson will appear in a later issue. General Session— Morning THE CHURCH OF MY CHOICE By Jennie B. Knight IT IS to Dr. George H. Brimhall that I am indebted not only for the choice of my church but also for the outline for this talk. One day while in my teens I said to him, "Father, you think I am a Mormon, but I am not and do not intend to be one." His wise answer calmed my rebellious heart and gave me food for thought. Putting his arm around me, he said: "If being a Mormon won't give my little girl more happiness than anything else in the world, I don't want her to be a Mormon." That was all, and the subject was never referred to again. As. The years have passed and I have been privileged to attend a church school, to work in the various auxiliary organizations, and to be present at church gatherings, I have found some characteristics of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that are not common to other churches. First: Our church is linked to heaven by divine authority. I believe that the same God who spoke to Moses in the burning bush and gave him commandments on Mount Sinai spoke to Joseph Smith in the Sacred Grove. Second: My church glorifies intelligence and declares that willful ignorance is a bar to salvation; that "the glory of God is intelligence, or in other words light and truth." Third: It holds sacred the free agency of man, giving every individual a right to go to God for himself, "Every soul who forsaketh his sins and cometh unto me, and calleth on my name, and obeyeth my voice, and keepeth my commandments, shall see my face and know that I am." (Doctrine and Covenants Section 93:1.) Fourth: My church provides for progress—eternal progress—through continuous revelation to those whose duty it is to administer church affairs. It accepts scientific discovery as part of God's truth and adopts that which is advantageous to the spreading of the Gospel or improvement of its members. It encourages its members to seek knowledge from all sources; to study and learn and become acquainted with all good books and with languages, tongues and people. Fifth: It recognizes recreation as pleasing to God. No ward is complete without its Primary festivals, Relief Society socials, Old Folks' gatherings and Priesthood outings. It has such confidence in youth that it has given the supervision of recreation to the young people. Sixth: We have our sacred temples where youth, maturity and old age meet in a common cause. Couples are here married for time and eternity; others are working for their dead. Seventh: My church honors and respects women; it grants them every opportunity for development in spiritual, intellectual and social 334 MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE lines. This great Relief Society was organized by the Prophet. Its weekly programs are unsurpassed; its avenues for service are unlimited. I rejoice in my affiliation with it; it has helped me to better appreciate my blessings. I understand now that my father knew the Mormon church and its value. Now I know some of the outstanding characteristics of the church of my choice — a place where faith in God will increase, where a love of Jesus Christ and His Gospel will grow, where a testimony of the divine mission of the Prophet Joseph Smith is to be had, where there is freedom through right living, growth by self-effort, happiness through altruistic service.  THE GOSPEL—A PRACTICAL WAY OF LIFE By Cora L. Bennion THE Savior said, "I am come that they might have life and that they might have it more abundantly." The abundant life is realized through the practical application of © the principles which Jesus taught as implied in another of his notable sayings, "Ye shall know the truth and the truth shall make you free." And again this knowledge is gained through obedience as indicated in another passage in the Gospel according to John, when Jesus answered the doubting multitude as he taught in the temple, "My doctrine is not mine, but his that sent me. If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself." The practical values of the Gospel are especially emphasized in the Epistle of James. He wrote: "What doth it profit my brethren though a man say he hath faith and have not works? Can faith save him? If a brother or sister be naked, and destitute of daily food, and one of you say to them, depart in peace, be ye warmed and filled; notwithstanding ye give them not those things which are needful to the body; what doth it profit? Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone. The same author tells us that, "Pure religion and undefiled before God and the Father is this, To visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and to keep himself unspotted from the world." This view of religion applies very directly to the purposes of the Relief Society. Women of this Organization have given generously of their time and strength both in pioneer days and also in recent times, in caring for the needs of the people, but what does it mean to keep oneself unspotted from the world? P Evidently it means to live in accordance with the moral teachings of the Gospel and to keep free from the sins of the world. This, however, is no real sacrifice since it is the only road to the enduring satisfactions of life, and to that joy which it was designed by the Creator that men and women should have. While Relief Society women have important community responsibili- ties, these should not detract from their home duties. This is especially true of mothers whose sons and daughters are still immature. Mothers and fathers are responsible for teaching the Gospel, both by precept and by example, to their children. * This calls for closely-knit family ties and intimate association of members of the family in their home life. The father's business often takes him away from home much of the time, leaving the mother to carry the major responsibility in the care and religious education of the family. It is not designed that Relief Society women shall neglect this duty. This does not mean that mothers should be RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 335 confined, like prisoners, to the home. They will be more competent for their home responsibilities if they keep in touch with the community life and know something of the social life and outside interests of their children. By these means and by wise use of leisure time for study, mothers may keep abreast of the times and continue to live in the same world as their children. This will help them to "be strong and of good courage" and to avoid the pitfalls of unwarranted fears and worties. The Gospel of Christ will help us to develop those soul satisfying aspects of living, and will help to eliminate the negative factors that destroy the joys of life. — BUILDERS OF TESTIMONY By Donna D. Sorensen F to every woman in the Church was put this question: "What do you desire most for your son or daughter?" the answer would come ringingly back from every true Latter-day Saint mother, "I would want my child to have, most of all, a testimony of the Gospel." Why a testimony? Because the Lord has said, "He that seeketh me early shall find me and shall not be forsaken." Because the strength of this Church lies in the individual testimonies of its members. Because to possess a firm, strong testimony acts as a way of life and points the direction as truly as a radio beam to the airplane. Because a testimony is the strongest shield one can have against "the fiery darts of the adversary". Through revelation in this dispensation Latter-day Saint parents have been told of the necessity of teaching their children the first principles of the Gospel, and so upon the women of Relief Society devolves this most important duty of the proper training and rearing of their children in the faith of the Gospel. The training of the human soul for advancement here and joy hereafter calls for the greatest possible powers of mind and heart. It is generally admitted that the first years of life are crucial in determining what the future of the child shall be spiritually as well as physically. The mother with a testimony herself in the divinity of Jesus Christ is given an authority and a certainty which she would otherwise lack. "To most of our young people the miracle of testimony is one of gradual 336 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE growth or development. Unknown to them, the mother's lullabies, the bedtime prayers, the family devotion... Are all making them converts." Teaching by example is especially important in the rearing of children. A mother should make it obvious that she is seriously interested in religious things and believes in them herself. To the Saints in this dispensation has come the command to teach their children to pray. Secret and family prayers and a blessing on every meal we eat all help "in forming a loving acquaintance with the Father". We might well ask ourselves this question: "How is the Relief Society fitting our women to be better participants in this great work of building testimonies in their families?" In our testimony meetings women are given the privilege to partake of that same spirit that they desire to inculcate in their families. Then, too, hundreds of women are weekly giving knowledge which they have to their sisters and in the giving are growing more able to give to their families. Many of our women are playing the part of the good Samaritan in their vicinities and doing good, and this, too, is one way to increase and grow in the knowledge of the truth. REPORT Eliza N. Salm, Oahu Stake Relief Society President EING surrounded by our Relief Society Singing Mothers, looking into your sweet, smiling faces, and with the feeling I have that my beloved people back home are praying for me, gives me courage to stand before you this morning. My dear sisters and friends, President Louise Y. Robison and her co-workers, my Alo-haa nui loa! When Sister Robison came to visit our island, we greeted her with aloha; that means aloha from within our hearts, the old way of the Hawaiians when they greet their loved ones. My heart is filled with gratitude to my Father in Heaven for the privilege we have of coming to your beautiful land. The Saints from Hawaii—the land of sunshine, flowers, music and singing—extend their greetings and alo-ha nui to you all. Six of us, Relief Society mothers, left our homes and loved ones and traveled thousands of miles to come to your beautiful land to participate in this conference. 'Three members of our stake board are here with me and two Relief Society ward presidents, one a mother of sixteen children, of whom fifteen are living and three attending the University of California. The few moments I occupy I sincerely ask my Father in Heaven to help me that I may be able to say those things that will make you proud of what we are doing in our Stake of Oahu. On December 13, 1850, the first missionaries arrived in the Hawaiian Islands, George O. Cannon and his companions. Twenty-five years later, on July 6, 1875, the first Relief Society was organized at Laie, on the Island of Oahu. Laie is my birthplace, and it is where the Temple now stands—one of the most beautiful sites on the islands and one most frequently visited by tourists. Relief Societies aré now organized on all the islands of the group. 'There were fifty-five branches under the leadership of the mission presidents. Much was done. The Relief Society had charge of the care of the missionaries at this time. I want to tell you that your sons and daughters are Our sons and daughters, and we love them all. We saw that their clothes were laundered, fed the poor, and cared for the sick. The missionaries instructed the Hawaiian sisters in the ways of today—sewing, cooking and so forth. The Gospel has been preached by the sisters traveling for miles on foot, visiting the Saints scattered here and there. As time has gone on, the work has progressed. Several hundred sisters are now within our fold and are doing much good. The art of handcraft has been part of our work—weaving mats, fans, hats, purses, cushions and other artistic pieces of the lauhala. Crepe paper leis, imitating the tropical flowers, have been made; the tourists would not go home without them. We have also made layettes and quilts. When Sister Robison visited our island, we presented her with an Hawaiian quilt. The sale of handwork has been a means of raising money to build up. Our funds. It was during the leadership of President Castle H. Murphy that changes were made on the Island of Oahu. August 4, 1931, the Relief RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 337 Societies on the Island of Oahu were placed under the direction of a district board. It was my privilege and opportunity to serve on this board for two years. Later I became president of the district board. It was difficult for us to change from the accustomed way of doing things. Later, in 1935, President Heber J. Grant came to Hawaii, and it was then that the Island of Oahu became a Stake of Zion—the only one in the group of islands. 'The officers of the district board were appointed the Oahu Stake Relief Society Board. From then on the responsibility was ours. We realized the load was heavy. We were inexperienced for this high position, not having had much education, but Heavenly Father has been very kind, and we have been led through His guidance. FE have been carrying out instructions from our General Board and have tried to equip ourselves to the best of our ability, although we have come upon a lot of difficulties, especially in the Literary work. 'The Hawaiian sisters have not had much education; most of them have only gone to school up to the fourth or fifth grades. We speak the Hawaiian and English languages in our meetings, trying to interpret to the best of our ability, so as not to lose anything which is outlined for us. The Hawaiian race have their own way of preserving their legends. So far they have not had books printed, but they have been taught from father to son, from generation to generation. While the mission Relief Societies 338 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE — took care of all charity work, the bishop of each individual ward now has charge of that work. We carry out instructions whenever any emergency comes up. We have the bishop's sanction before we carry out any charity work. The money paid out for charitable purposes comes out of fast offerings. The Relief Society, therefore, does not raise money as it did in the years past, but is allowed to raise money only in the month of March, all the wards and branches joining together and supporting the stake board in one big affair. A week before we left our islands, the Relief Society stake board gave a concert, dance, and bazaar to raise funds for our Relief Societies. 'There were over eight hundred cooperating in this great affair, which was held in connection with our Anniversary on the 17th of March. We are raising money for our contribution to the erection of our proposed tabernacle. We have had this privilege for the past eight years. On October 29 the Saints of Hawail prepared a luau. I am sure those who have been on a mission to the Islands know what that means. We fed eight thousand people. We served 4,000 pounds of pork, 4,000 pounds of poi—that is the main food of the people of Hawaii, 3,000 pounds of sweet potatoes, 1,500 chickens, 1,000 pounds of luau, 2,000 pounds of fish, 2,000 pounds of moss (sea weed), 5,000 coconuts, 500 boxes of starch — corn starch to make the Hawaiian pudding, 100 pounds of sugar, 20 tins of kilola, 240 cakes, 100 pounds of ice used for cold drinks. We served from 12 0'clock noon to 8 p.m. Twenty-five men prepared the imu, and fresh pork was served at each sitting. Twenty-five men served poi. There were 500 waiters, go for each sitting. Altogether there were 1,500 workers. I was in charge of the cakes, and of the leis. The Hawaiian sisters just love to make leis with their own hands, and we greet our missionaries with leis; but you greeted us with beautiful corsages when we arrived in your land. We can now see improvement in our work, and the interest and support has been wonderful. We are trying to support our General Board in the Membership Campaign, and we will do our best. It is our aim to support the Mormon Handicraft. I have brought with me handwork which our Hawaiian sisters have made as a token to our General Board. I want to testify to you that if it had not been for the Gospel we would not have left our loved ones and come to testify to you that God lives, that He hears and answers our prayers, and that Jesus is the Son of the Living God. May the choicest blessings of our Heavenly Father rest upon us this day, I pray in Jesus' name, Amen. Before the close of the afternoon session, two of the Hawaiian sisters brought leis to the tabernacle. Sister Salm put a lei on each member of the General Board, and also on the chorister and pianist, kissing Sister Robison as she presented the lei to her. This was very impressive. LOVE, THE NUTRIENT OF LIFE By Vivian R. McConkie OVE is a divine nutrient of human life and is the basis for all of our work. Jt motivates man toward the "bond of perfectness and peace". It strives for a fullness of life both here and hereafter. It stimulates thoughtful attention to the relationships of life. It is a native endowment of women, and expands heavenward as the subject grows in goodness. It encircles eternally those who do the will of the Father. It is manifested by the Son of God, through the Gospel. The atonement and the Holy Ghost evidence the extent to which it will reach to save us. It is inclusive of many qualities and is the mortar that holds the world together. It is a plant that matures beautifully or withers according to the cultivator of it. Let us surrender our personal pleasures and our ambitions in earnest endeavor to develop it. If so, then all things will work together for good. Love is expressed by words and deeds. True home culture can not exist without it. Its signs and tokens feed human affections. It is kind thoughts manifest in action; it perpetuates sentiment, considerations, and chivalry. When unexpressed it deteriorates. When expressed it refreshes parched places, and its sunshine awakens life. It continues courtship after marriage and is the sole remedy that will heal breaches that lead to broken homes. There is greater need for love than for modern comforts. If choice must be made between love and upto-date homes and automobiles, those who are touched with understanding will choose love and home and children and the standards of the Church as guide wires. If you would be loved be lovable, for love begets love. Like other gifts it must be used faithfully; otherwise it can not be enlarged. It must be active to reach the heart of another. Many hunger for it; yet, out of fear of encouraging vanity through lavish or unwise expressions of love many are allowed to starve for want of it. Malnutrition, where the element lacking is love, turns the heart to bitterness and the soul to rust. A wise word of recognition for a deed well done, or even for a failure, if the purpose was worthy, costs nothing and may greatly aid a worthy cause, as well as lighten a darkened soul. Love is measured by what it gives and by its purposes and its objects. The greatest love of all is manifest in the gift of eternal life, which is God's gift to all who desire righteousness. Man's greatest manifestation of love is to help persons to prepare themselves to receive eternal life, and the greatest thing that can be done to that end is to teach the truth. Our love is measured exactly by how completely we do this. If we love the Lord we will teach the Gospel, but we can not teach it if we do not live it. If we do not teach the truth it is because the light of truth is not in us. "I love thy testimonies." (Psalms 119:119.) ANALYZING VALUES IN PRESENT —DAY LIVING By Leda T. Jensen All of us were anxious to come to this world, created for our mortal probation. What are we doing each 'day with the life we came here to live? We all desire happiness, that inward peace and security that is the result of righteous living. What each individual does, what decisions he makes, what path he follows depends upon his sense of values. The most important aim of education is the evolution of a personal scheme of values. Our value concepts condition our appreciations and satisfactions. They determine our distant goals and our present decisions. As we learn to include in our daily living more of the esthetic, more of the ethical, and more of the spiritual values we hold highest, life takes on greater meaning and joy; it becomes more abundant. What has happened to us and our children biologically is a thing of the past. The environmental factors are immediately around us and in them are the possibilities for modification, adjustment and growth. Our social environment is a most intricate and complex one. The individual is being bombarded on every side by literally thousands of social influences, all of which are shaping the individual's ideas, attitudes, motives, and conduct. In the midst of the existing confusion, how is one to determine which values are necessary for peace and happiness? Where are we to turn for a guide, a pattern? Is public opinion a safe guide? Are the theories and philosophies of men infallible? Does the praise or ridicule of our friends and associates influence us in the standards we set? Sometimes it seems we know not which way to turn for inspiration. There is one sure source of right, one unerring pattern to which we may turn in spite of the complexity of modern living. Our Savior, Jesus Christ, has pointed out the way in the Gospel of the Master, given directly by Him or through his prophets to us. What about honesty, what about virtue, what about the Sabbath Day, what about using our leisure time, what about dealing fairly and justly with all of God's children? What the Savior has said about the matter should be the final tribunal. What would my Heavenly Father have me do should be our constant question. As Relief Society women, are our standards of living on the high level they should be? Are we assuming the great responsibility that rests upon us as mothers in Israel? Because of the confusion in the world about them children are probably more in need of the continuity and security that the home alone can give than they have ever been. After we have set our own house in order, we should strive constantly by precept and by consistent example to raise the morals of the neighborhood and the community in which we live. Then our lives will be truly happy, for we shall have that inward peace which comes from our Heavenly Father. If we honestly strive to follow His example, we shall be blessed to properly analyze values in presentday living and to live by those standards we know to be right. General Session—Afternoon OUR GREATEST HERITAGE By Counselor Kate M. Barker WITHOUT faith it is impossible to please God." Faith is pleasing to God because He knows how vital it'is to man. As we think of the distress in the world today, are we not every day of our lives filled with joy because our faith tells us that God does live, that there is meaning and purpose and continuity to life, that mght will prevail? But faith to be strong enough to endure must not stop at giving us comfort and a feeling of security. It must not only do something for us but make us do things. Faith is not an end to accomplish. It should rather be a starting point for new and greater things. The message of the Gospel to each of us is to get our values straight, then begin with ourselves, our homes, our communities. Our Relief Society lessons are planned to help us find the real values in life, which are faith in God, faith in the purpose, beauty and possibilities of life, and faith in one another. They are planned also to give practical help in applying our faith to works. 'The measure of their worth is whether the standards of home and community life are being raised. The great need of the world today is for leadership, and nowhere is it so needed as in the home. I like to think of Relief Society as a training school in leadership for mothers, providing such training as will result in higher home standards in the type of conversation, in the books read, in the love and unity of the family, in the spiritual life of the home. It is the sins of selfishness and unkindness which make for lack of love and unity in the home. 'These were the sins which Jesus hated above all else. Let us make faith in goodness easy for our children. There is so much happening today to tend to destroy faith in life. The home must make greater effort than ever to give youth the kind of faith which, though one is aware of the realities and difficulties of life, gives one an appreciation of the purposefulness of life and the courage and zest to meet life. If youth is to succeed it must thus face life. Another test of our lessons will be: Is our own and our children's love of the Gospel increasing? Is our faith strong enough to inspire them? Sister Spafford's little Scotch grandmother had a beautiful gold watch and chain. One day when a little girl Sister Spafford, who admired the watch, said to her grandmother, "Grandmother, will you leave me your watch and chain?" "My dear, I am leaving you something much more valuable. I brought it across the ocean from Scotland. It is the Gospel." What an impression to make on a little girl's mind and heart, especially when that testimony was corroborated by a wonderful life. The community is but the home 342 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE writ large, and woman's responsibility reaches there—the same responsibility which she has in the home —protecting the weak, caring for the sick and unfortunate, setting the standards of spiritual and cultural life. We all love to help. But in our complicated society the need for help is often not easy to see until tragedy comes. Our work is planned to help us understand human nature and the problems people are meeting today in order that we may be more sensitive to the needs of others and more understanding. The test of our success will be measured by the number of breakdowns which we prevent by extending a helping hand in time. How wonderful is the challenge our faith offers! A challenge so high it calls for the best of which we are capable. Jesus never minimized the discipline needed to be in His service. The Gospel asks us "not to be ministered unto but to administer". Opportunities for service are many. The chief causes of regret when we look back on life are the opportunities wasted, the responsibilities not met. Our faith is very precious to us. Let us resolve that nothing will rob us of it, that it will be active, that it will be the starting point for new and bigger things. Let us remember that our Father in Heaven was speaking to every member of the Church when He said, "Therefore O ye that embark in the service of God, see that ye serve Him with all your heart, might, mind and strength." If we do this our faith will never die. "We know whom we have trusted."
SOME FUNDAMENTALS By Counselor Amy Brown Lyman
THE confused and disturbed condition of the world today, with its abnormal social and moral conditions, its economic and industrial problems, its unemployment and unrest, has caused thinking men and women to wonder what important fundamentals have been overlooked or ignored in the world's economy, or in life itself, that such conditions are possible. Among the groups which are making a comprehensive and prayerful study of conditions is our own Church; and though we are a small group, as world groups go, the Church is trying to set its own house in order. It has realized the seriousness of the situation surrounding its people and is trying to help solve their social and economic problems. I was especially impressed with the gravity of world conditions last July when I attended a meeting of the International Council of Women in Edinburgh, Scotland, where I heard prominent women from 31 nations discuss the pressing problems of the day from many angles and from their various national and racial viewpoints. These ordinarily well poised women were greatly disturbed over the serious conditions in their respective countries. The European women especially were concerned, apprehensive and filled with doubts and fears. They had not forgotten the last war with its consequent hardships, sufferings and tragedies, and now they feared another. Earnest prayers were offered daily in this great convention that enlightenment would come to the world; that men's hearts would be softened and turned from hate, selfishness, greed and war; and that the Golden Rule might be revitalized and adopted universally as a guide. Social philosophers, economists, newspaper columnists and other experts in our country are daily discussing the complex situation and trying to point the way to recovery and to peace. Dr. Henry C. Link in his new book The Rediscovery of Man has made some interesting observations and constructive suggestions. He infers that much of our present-day trouble is due to the fact that the world has drifted too far away from the fundamental principles and standards developed by the past, too far away from the great moral laws set up in the Old Testament, too far away from the teachings and ideals of the Savior. He declares that conditions would improve readily if people would but accept these universal truths and follow these laws. Dr. Link's social philosophy in many respects is not unlike that of our own Church which a few years ago was re-emphasized and reaffirmed by the First Presidency when they issued a Recall to social service, to the Christian ideals of the brotherhood of man, to religion—applied faith and spirituality.
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 343
This great concerted effort on the part of the L. D. S. Church to help its people everywhere meet the complex conditions with which they are faced has been most inspiring and comforting to the people themselves, and has won the admiration of other groups. Definite objectives have been set up by the Church, the attainment of which will be sure to bring good results. The Church in its Welfare Program has been mindful of the values and lessons of the past; mindful of the abstract principles of right and wrong. It has stood firmly for those fundamental principles and standards and home-spun philosophies which have stood the test of time, which apply in all ages and which do not change even in a changing world. It has emphasized the fact that work, self-effort and self-reliance are basic elements of personal security and independence, and to this end it has sought to create work and opportunity; that industry, thrift and economy are the foundation stones of success in business and in home life; that too much social security weakens personal security; that honesty pays; that straightforwardness, dependability and integrity pay; that debt, whether national or personal, is bondage; that waste is calamitous; that installment buying is too expensive generally to be indulged in. In connection with this philosophy the Church, as always, seeks to develop faith in God and in His purposes, and obedience to the teachings of the Gospel. It is gratifying that the Relief Society is supporting and nobly assisting in this great Welfare Program.
344 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
The General Board is most grateful for and appreciative of the efforts put forth by Relief Society women in this additional work, as well as in carrying forward the regular cultural and educational program of the Organization. An article by President George H. Brimhall has stimulated me greatly. One excerpt from it I shall read. He asks and answers his own pointed question. It is: "Who are the honest, constructive, helpful members of the Church?" "They are those who pray for the poor and pay their fast offerings; they are those who pray for the building up of Zion, and pay their tithing; they are those who pray for the missionaries and contribute to their support; they are those who pray for forgiveness and forgive others; they are those who pray for health and keep the Word of Wisdom; they are those who pray for divine support of leaders, and stand for their counsel and advice." The Relief Society has just passed its 97th birthday. All down through its history it has been a faithful and loyal auxiliary to the Church, and a devoted aid to the Priesthood. It has been both conservative and progressive; it has looked both backward and forward, cherishing all of the virtues of the past but always facing bravely the needs of the future with its new conditions. At various periods during its existence the Organization has emphasized movements that were of particular importance to the women of each era. Since the day of its organization in 1842, one of its major activities has been welfare work. In this it has tried to use constructive, intelligent methods based on sound principles, tempered with love, sympathy and mercy. It has studied the problems connected with this work seriously. It has tried to keep constantly in mind the importance of normal life and opportunity for the individuals and families it has served. It has aimed to hold sacred their personalities and their confidences. It has tried to develop within them strength rather than weakness. And now it is giving its full strength, power and support to the Priesthood and the Church in this last great project. Relief Society women are constantly striving for greater knowledge and understanding of the world we live in—for knowledge of the laws of health, science, economics, morals and religion. Their chief study, however, is religion—the Gospel of Jesus Christ. They stress the importance of good homes and the proper rearing of children. We as Latter-day Saints have constantly been taught that the great object of the Church is to assist in the establishment of the Kingdom of God here on this earth. Recently in an address before the students of Brigham Young University Brother Stephen L Richards discussed the subject in a most interesting manner. He began thus: "How can we establish the Kingdom of God? By living, teaching, and establishing the laws of that Kingdom. What are the laws of that Kingdom? They are the decalogue and the Gospel of Jesus Christ." Relief Society women stand firmly for the observance of the great moral laws of the Bible. They stand firmly for the Gospel of Jesus Christ which has been fully restored. Their constant desire is to observe all the laws of the Kingdom, to live up to
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 345
all of the teachings and requirements of the Gospel and to be considered and known as orthodox Latter-day Saints.
ADDRESS By President Louise Y. Robison
WE are near the close of this wonderful Conference. I wish I had words to express my appreciation to our Heavenly Father for His Spirit that has been with us, for the beautiful weather we have had, and for these marvelous singers. In all my life I have never heard anything lovelier, and I do not expect to, not only in this life, but in eternity. It gives me great joy to give these sisters a blessing for themselves and for their families who have made sacrifices in order that they might come, some of them a long way. We have been blessed with the visit of our Hawaiian sisters. I am sure those who have had contact with them will never forget their wonderful testimonies, their loving, sweet spirits, their beautiful, colorful leis, and how freely they have helped us in all of our gatherings. I have never experienced anything more thrilling in my life than my visit to these wonderful women—to their wonderful people. I said at the time, I had wondered when I was a young woman why missionaries were sent to those far-away islands when we were just settling this valley and hardly had homes of our own—why send missionaries such a long distance to the Sandwich Islands? But when I met these people, saw their faith—the real blood of Israel—I could see why. I am sure you will let me express to Sister Salm and her sisters our love for them, and our aloha, and ask them to take it to their people when they return home. We have so many things for which to be thankful. A few days ago I picked up a little book that President Grant had given me, entitled Finding God in Millersville. I had read this interesting narrative many times, but never before realized that the ideas which changed Mr. Thornton from a man who did not believe in God to an earnest, ardent worker for humanity were the very principles which were given to Relief Society by the Prophet Joseph Smith. Those of you who have read the book will remember Mr. Thornton's early business life; he was quite sure there was no God and thought only of material profit. Then a change came. Let me read a few paragraphs: "Gradually, as I got nearer to my people, they began to move in close to me. Without realizing it until long afterward I had made my first great religious discovery. I had discovered my fellow men—my brothers. The closer I got to them, the more I admired them. The amount of love, and patience and simple faith in the average lowly man and woman became to me nothing short of marvelous. Men whom I had always regarded as rather slow-
346 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
witted, ordinary fellows, I found to be real heroes when I got under their skins. Human personality became to me the most marvelous and precious and wonderful thing in the world." It is the human personality which Relief Society is trying to develop; it is seeing beyond the service the real heroes and heroines and meeting them with love and patience. As evidence I have here a report of the activities for last year of our wonderful women. Only last month the stakes were asked for a report of the work done by Relief Society for the Church Welfare. This is entirely distinct from the annual Relief Society report. One hundred twelve stakes responded within two weeks' time. This is the compiled report: 629,325 quarts fruit and vegetables canned. 7,792 pounds fruit and vegetables dried. 195 glasses jelly. 25 pounds soap. 2,676 quilts made. 84 rugs made. 1 mattress and 5 sheets made. 11,902 articles of clothing—this includes 17 layettes. $12,422.01 in cash. Seventy-five stakes reported successful gardens planted. Figures, however, do not tell the real story. If there were time I would like to read the 112 reports, as they are all equally inspiring, but as that is not possible I have taken a few of the first received at the office: "In January, 1938, a cooperative program on sanitation, beautification and thrift was carried out by the Elders' Quorums and the Stake Relief Society. A definite assignment was given for each month from January to October. The program included fighting flies and weeds, planting vegetable and flower gardens, installing and painting sanitary toilets and rest rooms, and screening doors and windows. The climax was a flower show in September which was a grand success. A great deal of activity was reported, our visiting teachers and the elders gathering the reports. An educational questionnaire was carried by the stake board on special visits to wards. The object of this was to teach mothers how to buy, and what should be made and produced at home to meet the minimum standard of living. There was splendid response to this. In June, 1938, the ward bishops and Relief Society presidents made a survey of the welfare produce and clothing on hand in their wards. The results of this survey were compiled and a system of exchange of produce between wards was carried on, which was a great help." Another stake reports: "A year ago it was called to our attention that our stake was at the very bottom of the list in our region when it came to the payment of fast offerings. We knew that the success of the Welfare Plan rested largely upon the payment of fast offerings together with other voluntary contributions. So we, as Stake Relief Society officers, decided we would try and do something about it inasmuch as it is the mother in the home who plans the meals, orders the groceries and administers much of the family income. Therefore, we felt that the women in our stake were just as much to blame for the condition as the men were." Plans were made and executed and the report concludes: "While we do not wish to claim credit for this, there has been a substantial increase in fast offerings during the last year." Another stake reports: "Ninety-three families have been taught how to can their own fruits and vegetables, with the use of a pressure cooker. Six hundred eighteen hours have been spent in sewing—sixty-eight women donating their services and ninety-six women being instructed. Twenty-eight women sewed one article for themselves and one article for the Welfare Center. Thirty families have been assisted with new and used clothing and quilts. Several talks on beautification and gardening have been given in each ward. Plants, seeds and bulbs have been exchanged, very choice flowers raised, many homes painted, meeting houses and grounds improved and some vacant lots cleaned of weeds. Where school delinquency is found to be due to lack of proper clothing, we have supplied this so that children might continue their school work and feel at ease with other children." From another stake the Relief Society officers of all the wards urged the women to raise good gardens and can surplus vegetables and fruit for winter use. If any of the women did not know how to use a pressure cooker someone was sent into the homes to teach them. There was also much surplus canning done in the homes and turned over to the bishops for Church Welfare. One ward reports they have a family where the mother is nearly blind. Relief Society women do the sewing, mending and darning for this family as well as supplying the needed bedding. Only three days after Sister Lund
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 347
had sent the request for these reports, the following report was received, written by hand: "We have a stake sewing center well supervised by an efficient Relief Society sister where women from all our wards come to work. Some of these women have been taught sewing from the first step. We also have a loom, with one of our women in charge, where hundreds of yards of rugs have been woven for the needy and also for custom work." One stake prepared its report under "Wards," "Priesthood Projects," and "What Relief Society Did Toward Helping the Projects." Where the Priesthood project was the production of sugar beets, the Relief Society women served hot dinners to 60 men in the spring at time of planting, and again to 35 men when the crop was harvested. Where tomato and corn raising were the projects, Relief Society canned 1,600 cans of tomatoes and dried 750 pounds of corn. This stake reports this interesting item: "During the summer months of last year the janitor in one of the wards asked his bishop for a two months' leave of absence. The general fund of Relief Society in that ward was entirely depleted, so the president asked the bishop to let the women do the janitorial work for those two months, receiving the janitor's compensation. This was done and the Relief Society general fund was increased $80." One stake reports: "$600 has been contributed to the stake presidency for welfare purposes by the stake Relief Society. Eight hundred articles of remodeled clothing have been supplied, and Relief Society women have been sent into
348 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
the homes to teach and assist the families in sewing. The Relief Society furnished 354 women and the bishops 82 men to do 940 days' canning. One ward conducted a farm project in which 30 women spent 4 days cutting corn from the cob. These same ward Relief Society women donated the food and served 125 meals to men while they labored on this ward farm. Several of our wards have purchased cookers and sealers and paid a woman to go into the homes of needy families to take care of fruit furnished by the bishop, or vegetables grown in their own gardens. As a special project to help forward the Church Welfare Program, the Relief Societies have made a plea for every home to have a garden. The response has been very commendable. A very large per cent of our members have grown sufficient vegetables to supply their own needs as well as to can for winter use." THESE reports are so interesting and vital that I find it difficult to leave them. I must read one more item and this time I shall mention the name. I quote: "Walla Walla did a unique thing. This ward was not a part of our stake when the budget allotment was made, but they desired to do something for the welfare work. Each woman received ten cents from the Organization, and was asked to put the ten cents to work and bring back as much as she could from the investment. One woman bought eggs, set a hen, sold fryers and returned $1.50. Another sister bought ten cents worth of beans and brought back $5. Another invested in tomato seeds and returned $3." I could tell you many interesting happenings, but from the money invested Walla Walla Relief Society purchased two barrels of flour for the storehouse. An outstanding item from one of the stakes reads: "Members of Relief Society in one ward cared for two little motherless girls while the older children attended school for nine months." I feel very much like Sister Wendelboe of Cache stake, who added a postscript to her reports as follows: "Our activities are many more than the ones I have reported, but the women do so many kind and thoughtful acts, and when they have finished they think no more about them; so in this way many activities are not reported." If the Savior were to ask today, as He once asked His disciples: "What do ye more than others?" these reports would be the answer. This type of activity is only one phase of Relief Society work; it does bring us close to the needs of others. In our desire to serve those of our Father's children who are in distress, we strengthen our own faith. We realize that our first responsibility is to our children, to teach them faith in God and help them to understand the principles of the Gospel. In this important work, women receive help through Relief Society. Mothers gain insight into many problems of child-life by discussing their problems with other earnest women who are eager to improve. Young mothers are benefited by the calm faith of older sisters who have reared their families. Only recently a young grandmother expressed concern that her daughter and other young mothers today do not have the faith-promoting influence of mothers and grandmothers, as girls and young women of her generation had—women who had joined the Church in foreign countries, who had given up comfortable homes, and without regret had walked across the plains and established homes in a new country. Their testimony of the truthfulness of the Gospel, and the calm positive assurance of the power of faith had a lasting effect upon the lives of young people. Relief Society must try to develop this same faith. We must help our young people to distinguish between the essentials and non-essentials in life. In a recent testimony meeting a member of the General Board told us of an early experience which had stayed in her memory all her life. Her father had taken a load of hay to the city, and it was long past the time when he was expected home. The mother was greatly worried, but she took her very small children into the bedroom with her, and each of them offered a prayer for the father's return. A short time after this mother and her children had prayed, the father came. Prayer was answered. To those small children this established the fact that there was a Father in Heaven who did answer prayer. This was a beautiful foundation—so easy to establish, but wise mothers must continue to build. Faith is peculiar—it can grow stronger even in the face of hardship and sorrow, or it can and does leave if one neglects to nourish it. The more prayer becomes a regular habit, the easier faith grows. Mothers who keep the Sabbath Day as we are taught it should be observed, who help children to understand
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 349
why, who teach them the sacred privilege of partaking of the Sacrament, the importance of honesty, truth and sharing with others, make faith in God a part of their lives. I pray God our Father that He will bless you, and let us blend our prayers with those of the heart-broken women of Europe—our sisters—that their burdens will be lightened. May our Father bless you with influence in your homes that your children will love the Gospel. One of the sweetest things that can come to parents is to have a child know the Gospel is true, and have a desire to work for it. I do want to thank you for coming to this conference; it has been a joy. My heart is so full of gratitude to my Heavenly Father. We have prayed for this conference, that we might give you something that would help you carry on your work. A week or ten days ago the General Board of Relief Society held a fast meeting, a prayer meeting, that our Father in Heaven would bless us both yesterday and today and throughout this conference, that you sisters would have the Spirit of the Lord, and bring it with you and have your hearts filled with it. I want to thank Him for answering our prayers. I want to thank you for making these prayers possible. May God bless you and take you home in safety and keep you until we meet again I ask in His name, and I do it with all the earnestness of my heart. I do know that God lives; I do know that He answers our prayers; I do know that He loves you sisters who work for His children; and I do know that He will bless you.

Teach-Tithing Campaign
ONCE again we call the attention of Relief Society organizations to the annual Church-wide teach-tithing campaign. From the Progress of the Church we quote: "A short talk on tithing is planned to be given in every meeting of Aaronic or Melchizedek Priesthood, and all of the auxiliary associations, during the month of May." The influence of mothers upon family members with regard to the observance of this great law is a potent one. "A wife and mother fully converted to the law of tithing usually means a household where this obligation is met." We desire all Relief Society organizations to give careful attention to the request of the Presiding Bishopric that short talks be given at the regular meetings during the month of May.

LESSON DEPARTMENT FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS Youth Faces A World Of Change Lesson 8 By Paul Popenoe, Sc. D. (Director Institute of Family Relations, Los Angeles, California)
YOUTH always faces a new world,—new to it,—but the present younger generation faces two conditions that no younger generation has faced in American history: I. They are fewer in number, therefore more in a minority. In the past, this has been a nation of youth. The frontier was pushed back, the West was conquered, the Civil War was fought by young men,—largely a group that would now be "college boys". Taking 21 as an arbitrary line of division, it will be found that 75 years ago half of the entire population of the United States was under 21 years of age. The falling birth-rate has changed this situation. In the United States as a whole only one-third of the population, in Southern California scarcely more than one-fourth, is under 21 years of age. In other words, where youth was formerly in equal numbers with its elders, it is now outnumbered two to one, or, in Southern California, three to one. This is becoming a nation of old people, who are inevitably inclined to run things from their own point of view and unconsciously for their own benefit (witness the great crop of old-age-pension schemes). Inevitably, this tends to make the young feel that there is no place for them in the world. This deprives society of the enthusiasm, idealism, and energy of youth, which it sorely needs; and probably tends to make youth more radical and revolutionary, more inclined to protest more violently, than is normal for adolescence; they feel so much outnumbered that they think they can attract attention only if they shout,—to speak figuratively.
II. The gap between the older and younger generation is becoming greater than ever, due mainly to city life, where the children and parents have so little effective association,—as compared with farm life where the whole family shares in a co-operative enterprise. This intensifies the feeling of youth that it is not an integral part of society but a group apart, in opposition to, and in conflict with, the older generation. Many of the results of this changing situation are familiar to every thoughtful person. For example:
1. Small families (the average in the educated part of the American population is now two children, which means that there are just as many families smaller than this, as there are larger) give the child less chance to learn family relations, to acquire the habit of give-and-take, to practice the invaluable art of respecting other people's rights; of protecting himself from the older and stronger while in turn protecting the younger and weaker. Parents may have more time for work, more freedom for play, if they have fewer children (obviously, they would have still more if they were childless, and some deliberately adopt this extreme course); but this is offset by the lack of that experience which parenthood brings to the enrichment of life, and is also offset tragically by the greater loneliness and feeling of frustration and failure later in life. During the World War a German psychologist published a study of 100 married couples, each of whom had had but one child, a son, and had lost this only child in battle. It was a tragic story of defeat and despair that the interviews brought to light. But disease or accident may leave parents childless, just as surely as
war. Beyond this, history is filled with the remarks of those who, at the close of a life spent in the pursuit of fame, have described bitterly the futility and disillusionment of it all, agreeing with The Preacher that "All is vanity." But I do not remember ever reading of a father who, after successfully bringing up a worthy family, expressed regret over a misspent life. 2. The modern family is more independent,—too often detached from its kinship. The whole burden of making a success in life is placed on two young people,—husband and wife,—without the help they would have had, in the pioneer period, from friends and relatives. At the same time, there are fewer social RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, MAY - 355 controls,—less pressure on them to make a success of marriage. They are perhaps in a large city where no one knows them and no one cares what happens to them. Society seems determined to make it as hard as possible for them to succeed, as easy as possible for them to fail! High schools and colleges, even some churches, have been slow to do anything practical that would enable young people to marry more successfully. Fortunately, a nationwide interest in the subject is now manifest, and conditions are changing for the better. The spread of family relations courses in the schools, the establishment of clinics and counseling centers like the Institute of Family Relations in Los Angeles, will make it possible for many persons to get help who in the past have groped blindly. 3. The modern, urban family is loosely integrated,—it is not a tightly knit unit (one for all and all for one) like the pioneer family which more nearly represents the normal, biological, family unit. There is less training for character and citizenship in it (no matter how much responsibility the schools may assume, the home must still take primary responsibility for training children in character, religion, health, and recteation), because there is less sharing of activity. The family's advantages in this respect increase proportionately with the number of children it contains. The farm family has a great advantage over the city family. Every measure that strengthens rural life, that gives the farmer justice, that makes the farm more attractive to young people and keeps them on it, 356 - MAY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE is indirectly a measure to strengthen the nation's family life. The farm family does for its members, naturally and well, a lot of things that the city schools can do for their pupils only with difficulty and at great expense. 4. The family is individualistic. Each child gets more attention, and the individual rather than the family is the collective unit. 'This makes it hard for the child to adjust to life later, when he goes out into the world and has to get along with other people. The resulting lack of "'adjustability" is a handicap in many ways. Some young people fail to marry, because they have not learned how to get along with others. Dr. Joseph K. Folsom has calculated that, where a girl one hundred years ago could choose a satisfactory husband if she had five eligible men to select from, her granddaughter today must know 25 eligibles in order to have a chance to make as satisfactory a choice as her grandmother made. This results from the greater variety of patterns and backgrounds (emphasized in the first lesson of this series) and the less tolerance that people today have. Incidentally, how many unmarried young women today actually know 25 eligible men? There is probably less harmony among those who do marry. It is sometimes alleged that the increasing divorce rate does not show married people to be less happy than in "the old days," but merely that they will not put up with as much unhappiness as their ancestors did. Where their ancestors suffered in silence, they will get a divorce. There is some truth in this, but it is far from the whole truth. No one can apply it seriously to such a condition as that existing in Los Angeles County, where an actual majority of all marriages end in the divorce courts! If it is true that we won't put up with difficulties the way our grandparents did, it is also true that we can't,—we have never learned how. The consequence is an increase in all sorts of maladjustments, neuroses, and actual insanity, as well as in marital misery. Such problems as these urgently demand attention today. Families of normal size, with the children growing up to be "family-minded," will avoid many of the social and emotional difficulties associated with the present all-too-common one- and two-child households. A more closely knit family life, with more systematic preparation of young people for marriage and more help available for them after they marry, will have far-reaching influence on the happiness and success in life of both older and younger generations.
Questions and Problems
1. Do you think that a "Youth Movement" helps to promote better family life?
2. What sort of chores can be found for the children of a city family, that will help them to feel that they have a real part in the work of the world?
3. What makes some women think home-makers inferior to women carrying on careers outside the home?

Our Cover
THE BRIGHAM YOUNG MONUMENT was unveiled July 20, 1897, as a part of the Jubilee Festivities commemorating the semi-centennial celebration of the entrance of the Pioneers into the valley of Salt Lake. Elder James H. Moyle, in behalf of the Brigham Young Memorial Association, presented the monument to the public, and President Wilford Woodruff proclaimed, "In the name of God I now unveil this monument," and the stars and stripes fell away from the heroic figure of Brigham Young. Governor Heber M. Wells then said: "I now accept this monument in honor of Brigham Young and the Pioneers.
"Let us, my fellow citizens, here and now, in the presence of these surviving pioneers, whose forms are bent with toil, whose heads are whitened by the frosts of time and whose hearts are throbbing with gratitude to God that they have lived to see this day—and in the presence of all this honorable attendance let us resolve to guard well this monument, to shield it from the vandal and the marauder, to keep it as a solemn trust, to treasure it as a sacred heritage.
"As we look upon its sculptural beauty, let the granite of its base, hewn from our own mountain fastnesses, denote the hardy heroism of the men and women who founded and reared this splendid commonwealth; and let the bronze statue, carved by our native sculptor (Cyrus E. Dallin), symbolize the civilization and culture to which our people have attained.
"And now let me indulge the hope that this monument may stand on this historic spot as stands these rugged hills—'rock-ribbed and ancient as the sun'; that it may endure as they endure down through the ages and be remembered ever as a tribute of respect paid by a grateful people to their pioneers, as an emblem of half a century of wisdom, progress and as an offering of peace and good will to the blended brotherhood of Utah."
Elder B. H. Roberts in the Tabernacle that afternoon in addressing the pioneers said, "... I congratulate you that the monument which you have erected speaks only of that which is good. It will not speak of man's victory over his fellows, it will not commemorate scenes of carnage and desolation, the groans of the dying and the shouts of the victors. It speaks of the triumphs of peace, of the victory of mind over matter, of fertility over sterility; such is the story it will tell to future generations..."
