The will and power to make our destinies, To seek, to choose, to cherish, and to work; The right to worship how and where we please— God gave; we must not, dare not, shirk
The task, the joy, of passing on this creed To those whose strength must serve tomorrow's need. —Cleone Montgomery. The Relief Society? Magazine Vol. XXVI Woman As An Interpreter ~ Of The Faith By Maude Beeley Jacob "A woman's rank lies in the fullness of her womanhood." WOMEN today point with pride, and justly so, to their accomplishments in the professions, the arts, commerce, industry, education, and politics. Today, the position and service of woman is elevated to a point never before attained; today, the power and responsibility of woman is most potent. In this new pride of achievement one pauses to ask, is the ancient pride of the mother of the Gracchi forgotten? In this new elevation of responsibility is woman neglecting her place in the trinity of father, mother, and child? Many and varied are the opinions of those who are considering the role of woman in the world of today. In discussing the heritage of woman, invariably the emphasis is placed upon her ignominious role as the possession of man in the ancient world. Anathemas re still being hurled at Eve for the woes of man and the world generally. The long struggle of emergence from "female to woman" receives much historical attention. Feminism and anti-feminism call for many a eulogy and many a diatribe. The pessimist looks to the future of civilization with alarm as he claims that because woman has stepped out of her role family and fireside have "left the house". To reveal the delusion of equality woman is constantly reminded that a woman has not yet been a Shakespeare, or a Newton, or a Michelangelo, or a Beethoven. Of the divinity of woman, her place in the scheme of creation, what has been said? Of the age-old role of woman, that of mother-teacher, her supreme contribution, what is needed most to be said? That which will bring to the heart of woman the conviction that: "God has placed the genius of woman in their hearts, because the works of this genius are always works of love." In the great heart of woman her significance intellectually, politically, or socially is not the supreme issue. Now, as of old, she accepts her dual role, that of mother and of teacher. Today, the sanctity of the home rests primarily upon marriage. The entire future of civilization depends upon parenthood. "To open the capacities of body, mind, and spirit, so that life may flow in upon a young soul" is the mission of motherhood. To this double-natured motherhood St. Augustine pays tribute as he records his eulogy of his mother, Monica: "She was twice my mother, brought me to birth in the flesh, that I might be born into this earthly light; in heart that I might JULY, 1939 No. 7 436 - JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE be born into light eternal." Ibsen, the keen analyst of the social forces that have molded our modern civilization, saw the significance of woman's dual role: "Women will solve the question of mankind, and they will do it as mothers. They will serve also as teachers, the earliest of schoolrooms being the mother's knee." From the pages of the great literary expression of the ages as well as from the creations of art and sculpture it is in this dual role which woman stands glorified and immortalized. S the "Mothers of Israel" lie revealed in the lives of the women of the Old Testament, it is the mother-love of the mothers of Moses and Samuel we turn to for inspiration. It was the mother-love that inspired the mother of Moses to place her babe that the woman-heart of Pharoah's daughter might cause his life to be spared. It, too, was her task to keep alive in her child's soul the faith of his fathers, trust in the God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, a preparation which was to make him ready to be called by God to deliver Israel. It was gratitude for the gift of motherhood that gave Hannah courage to fulfil her promise and prepare her son, Samuel, for God's service. Directing the boy's earliest thoughts toward Jehovah she related the great events in the history of the Hebrews, the lives of great leaders were told and retold with pride of detail; for in the Talmud Hannah had read, "Who is best taught?" also the answer, "He that is taught by - his mother." To her this was her sacred obligation. After her son was accepted for service in the temple, Hannah's task received its approbation. Then yearly she went to present the family sacrifice, taking with her the garments she had fashioned with her own hands for her son to wear. This was her joy and her renewing. The reward of Hannah as of the mother of Moses came in the service of the sons that they had prepared for God's great purposes. Christianity, through Mary of Nazareth, the mother of Jesus, brought to the earth the divinity of motherhood. 'To us today Mary, the Mother, is a mystical figure unless her life is re-created out of the historical fabric of the New Testament. At her knee Jesus learned the record, laws, and wisdom of the Jews. To Joseph and Mary as Hebrew parents the training of a son was a serious responsibility. By the age of twelve he must know the commandments of Moses, the six hundred other laws that had been added to them, also the two hundred and fifty-eight forbids, for Judaism had become a religion of exacting discipline. Then there was the historical record of the Old 'Testament to know in detail as well as the wisdom of the prophets. Knowing as she did the divinity of Jesus and expecting the fulfillment of the Messiahship, how sacred the early training of the boy Jesus must have been to Mary. How she must have followed with eager concern the preparation for the first Passover at Jerusalem; how anxious for the approbation of the learned rabbis for her son's preparation, preparation for the divine mission. Throughout the ministry of Jesus we lose sight of Mary. Mary Borden in the biography Mary of Nazareth paints an unforgettable picture of the unrevealed nother of Jesus. It may err in detail, but in portraying the heart of Mary, the mother, it is a revelation of the mother-heart of womankind: It is a Sabbath evening and Mary is teaching Joseph and Jude, her grandchildren, one of the holy traditions that was to rule their lives. "'Say it, children," she urged; "with what materials may the Sabbath lamps be lighted and with what may they not be lighted?" But before the little ones could answer, Mary's mind had wandered to Jesus teaching His new and surprising doctrine in Galilee. Strange reports had come to the tiny home in Nazareth to the effect that Jesus had been cast out of the synagogue for breaking the Law. Mary begged to be taken to her Son thinking that she could make peace with his enemies by pleading with Jesus to refrain from antagonizing the priests. But James had refused his mother, cautioning her to have nothing more to do with her son. At last Mary started out alone. Always she missed Jesus for He had gone on to Jerusalem. Then came the day when with Mary of Bethany and Mary of Magdala, the women who understood the mission of Jesus, she stood by the cross on Calvary. "These women who were the last at the cross and the earliest at the grave." Thus we see in Mary, the mother of Jesus, a pattern of motherhood often puzzled and bewildered, yet trusting implicitly to the end. Good women have been the vehicles of divine inspiration and influence to the world continually. Few, however, like Cornelia, the Roman matron, have been honored by such a tribute for giving noble sons to the service of their country as she was in the statue erected with RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, JULY - 437 the inscription, "Cornelia, the Mother of the Gracchi." Great mothers have seemed "unhonored and unsung" each generation, but from their combined efforts have arisen the refining factors of civilization. To man's material world of conquest and dominion they have brought the things of the spirit, "an influence constantly exerted on father, husband, son, or friend, a power wielded from the family hearth to the homes of science and the halls of legislation'. O the women of today the Prophet Joseph Smith brought the true significance of woman's place in God's plan of creation—the great principle of an Eternal Mother as a partner with the Father in the heavenly spheres. Women's rights in the modern sense in the light of this sublime truth fade into nothingness. The divine right of woman is to participate in the spiritual gifts of the. Gospel through the holy Priesthood.. Man and Woman! Truly, "they rise or fall together, dwarfed or God-like, bond or free." When the roll of honor is called of the "Mothers of Mormonism," the mothers of the prophetic leaders of the Church will lead the list by royal right of the glorious sons they bore, God's chosen servants in the Dispensation of the Fullness of Times of the everlasting Gospel. From different lands and creeds and cultures they came but with one outstanding characteristic, a deep and abiding faith in God. Lucy Mack Smith, mother of the Prophet Joseph Smith, will head the roll of honor. Keen of intellect, benevolent in heart and understanding in spirit she accepted the calling and teach- 438 - JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE ings of her son. Through persecution, suffering, and martyrdom she remained faithful to the cause of right. Brigham Young carried with him through life the memory of a mother whose gentle manners, refined taste, and beautiful devotion influenced so completely the lives of her children. A mother whose tact and sympathy mellowed the Puritan sternness of the father. A mother who taught her children their letters and what little schooling she knew. Whose admonitions were "Always to honor the name of the Father and the Son; to revere the Holy Book and observe its precepts." The life of Mary Fielding Smith, the mother of President Joseph F'. Smith, is the record of a heroine in very deed by reason of her greatness of spirit and soul. Her glorious faith, her indefatigable industry, her personal charm, and her glorious courage are a noble pattern for the young womanhood of today to know and to emulate. The mothers of Wilford Woodruff, John Taylor, and Lorenzo Snow, take their places in the gallery of our honored women as we know and appreciate them through the lives of our revered leaders. So often has the beautiful life of Rachel Ivins Grant been made the illustration of noble precepts and testimony that we honor her for her own life as well as for the life of our living Prophet and Leader. To the noble woman, Eliza R. Snow, supreme in faith, superior in intellect, and a genius in expression the women of Mormonism owe the beautiful expression of the place of women in the philosophy of eternal progression. Taught the sublime truth by the Prophet Joseph Smith she gave it to the world as the poem, "O My Father," testifying to all mankind of the existence of an eternal motherhood. All that modern progress has done for woman is accepted, its liberation, its education, and its opportunities; all that women have achieved is accepted with gratitude as well as with pride. With a more complete understanding of her own mission comes the realization that whatever other role she wishes to combine with motherhood, be it industry, business, or professional life, is her prerogative, but her obligation remains unaltered in the motherteacher role. With the assurance that comes to the women of the Church of their place in the eternal scheme of the Creator what is the contribution which may be accepted of them? What is the great need of today? The great need of the world today is a true conception of the purpose of life; that God is the Eternal Father of all; that the laws of eternal progress are divine laws; that to each — individual falls the responsibility for his own acts; that personality is sacred; and that the greatest of all laws is the Divine law of Love. To fill her role as mother to her children is not all. As the mothers of Israel of old, she must be in very deed an interpreter of the faith, interpreting for them God, His laws and His love. 'To the women of her generation she must bring through the pattern of her life an interpretation of the true mission of motherhood. As the Gospel of Jesus Christ has brought to woman her greatest possession it should be now her greatest responsibility to make her life an interpretation of the Gospel of Jesus Christ. Recreation of the Pioneers By Juanita Brooks "A merry heart doeth good like medicine, but a broken spirit drieth up the bones." BRIGHAM YOUNG realized the literal truth of this Proverb and in all his colonizing programs encouraged the people in recreational activities, often "calling" aman to a newsettlement who could furnish music or who could direct the singing or dramatics. He knew from his experience in crossing the plains how often weary bodies were refreshed when hearts were uplifted in song or cheered by the dance. The hardships attending the establishment of the empire in Utah were no less strenuous than those on the plains, and the people were in as much need of recreation. I have been interested in the accounts of pioneer recreation found in some of the diaries which it has been my privilege to handle. The following excerpts were taken from a diary in which each day's activities were chronicled: "Jan. 1, 1882—-The whole town turned out today to help finish the new school house so we could dance in it tonight. I put in the windows and hung the door." "Jan. G—Storm. We could not hold Sunday School in the new school house today, the roof leaked too bad." 'April 10—Myself and wives attended the last day of school dance. Enjoyed myself well. The new school house is better than dancing in homes as we have done. By just a little crowding we can have three sets. The boys don't wring on so bad. Two wagon loads from M.........-.. Attended." (This was a town seven miles away.) Here certainly is more than meets the eye. How clearly is pictured the small building, as well as though the dimensions were given, with the thatched roof which leaked at the first heavy storm. We may be sure that the merrymakers who came in the wagons seven miles would be until almost morning getting home. Here is another account illustrative of the life in the smaller towns: Later in the fall the brethren got pine logs out of Little Pine Valley and Juanita Brooks of St. George found her great-grandmother's journal at the age of thirteen when she was helping an aunt with the house-cleaning. Tucked away in the back of an old secretary, securely tied around with calico string. The backs were loose, the pages yellow and brittle with age, but the handwriting was still clear and legible. She says, "Forgetting my work, I opened the journal and began to read. The room in which I sat with its whitewashed walls, its rag carpet stretched over a bulging layer of crisp, fresh straw, everything vanished, and I was with the Saints during the stirring days in Nauvoo." Thus she was initiated into a hobby which has become more fascinating with the years. She has had the privilege of reading more than a hundred handwritten originals, collected from homes in all parts of Utah, Arizona and Nevada. Some of them were daily diaries, some were made up of periodic entries, and some were They cover, one or another of them, the whole range of the history of the Church. The part in which Mrs. Brooks is most interested is that dealing with life in Utah, particularly in the smaller settlements. It was journals written from memory late in life. They cover, one or another of them, the whole range of the history of the Church. The part in which Mrs. Brooks is most interested is that dealing with life in Utah, particularly in the smaller settlements. JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE hewed them and built a meeting house 18 by 25 feet with a big stone fire place in one end. It was built at the west end of the fort, covered with lumber and dirt and ready for use on the first of Jan. 1868. To get wood to warm the house, they chose up sides. They were to work two hours, and the side that got beat was to furnish supper and a dance for the town.." These are typical of what happened in most of the settlements. Usually they cleared a place in the brush, leveled and dampened it, and danced, first under the open sky, later in a willow bowery, and still later in homes before a public building was finished. 'The music might be an accordion, or perhaps an orchestra composed of a violin with a guitar or organ accompaniment. Many a dance has been held to the music of a harmonica. The important thing was that they did have music of some kind. And the dances! There was the intricate pattern of the quadrille, the grace of the lancers, the dignity of the schottische, the rollicking fun of the reels, the speed of the polka which left everyone perspiring and breathless, along with one or two precious waltzes. 'The dances were conducted in an orderly way. They were opened and closed with prayer; the ladies stayed on one side of the hall and the men on the other, and no one selected his partner until the dance was called, when they would "fill up the floor" either in quadrille formation or promenade by couples. 'This gave the floor manager a chance to check and see that no one was "wringing on”. Each man was given a number and was allowed to dance only when his number was called. Energetic young fellows who wished to dance every time must buy more than one ticket. Among the poorer in the smaller towns. It was not unusual for two boys to alternate during an evening, using one ticket and the same pair of shoes. On the other hand, some of the dances were quite elaborate and formal in the larger centers, as their invitations show. One woman writes: "I have gone to as grand balls in Dixie as there was in Salt Lake City in the '60s, with every article I had on but my shoes spun and made at home. I felt just as well dressed as I ever have in my life. We took pains to make our dresses fine and nice, and have our dresses fit us good." Another from the same period but by a different writer: "Mrs. Pratt, the wife of the apostle, came to the dance for a few minutes. She wore a large crinoline and a dress with a skirt of seven widths of cloth, all gathered around the waist and gave the appearance of a bustle all around. I can never forget the grandeur of it." There were many occasions for holding dances. Regular holidays were always appropriately celebrated: Christmas, May Day, Thanksgiving, the Fourth of July, but perhaps more elaborately than any, the Twentyfourth of July. Often this was the occasion for parades with covered wagon trains attacked by Indians. This account is quite typical: "24 July 1867 celebrated in the new city under a spacious bowery. The people marched and rode to the bowery headed by the brass band. I drove the H...............carriage. After the services of song and speech, tables loaded with the peoples' picnic were surrounded and heartily partaken of. The afternoon was spent in visiting and games." Contests sponsoring some community activity were common: Haul- ing wood for the mecting house, graveling the sidewalks, killing off predatory animals, or cleaning the town canal. This was followed by a town dinner and dance. In addition there were "bees" of many kinds: Spinning bees, carpet-rag bees, quilting bees, and husking bees probably being most commion. The refreshments often consisted of molasses candy and parched corn, or raisins and almonds, although occasionally a supper was served. But whatever they ate, the spirit of cooperation and fun was present. THEY must make their own good times. Here was no commercial entertainment prepared and presented. For this reason, a play put on by local talent was usually a feature during the holiday week, while in some of the larger towns regular theatrical societies were organized and plays presented regularly and the proceeds given to some community enterprise. The late President A. W. Ivins, in a letter to Mrs. Zaidee Miles of St. George, tells how the first play in that town, "The Eaton Boy", was presented in the willow bowery, and his sister Caddie shocked the entire community by taking the part of a boy and appearing on the stage in pants. The records of the St. George Dramatic Company, organized a few years after the town was settled, show that for the presentation of the "Charcoal Burner" the proceeds totaled $51.40, of which $1.50 was cash and the remainder labor, molasses, dried fruit, wheat, etc. Produce was accepted as tickets in most of the early settlements. Several qualities mark the recreational activities of the Mormon pioneers, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, JULY 441 whether in large centers or small. One is their reaching out for culture, their striving to improve their gifts. Along with the strenuous business of wresting a living from the stubborn soil, they did not lose sight of these ideals. This entry, made at St. George, while the city was still a camp of wagons, illustrates this: "Here I may be allowed, with some degree of modest pride, to state that in the large tent furnished by Brother Asa Calkins I was first to give a lecture on English grammar, and had the honor of being one of the first group to take part in singing as a public choir while encamped." How revealing that short item is. What volumes it speaks for the type of people who made up our pioneering ranks, people who, in the midst of sand and sage, would sit in a tent on the ground and listen to a lecture on English grammar. I doubt that a parallel can be found in the settlement of any other state, certainly not in any of the mining towns of our neighbors. Another familiar institution was called the Lyceum, wherein young men trained themselves in matters of speech and information on history and government. The seriousness with which this was taken is shown by this entry from the diary of a man then in his early twenties: "I have had a good time attending mectings this winter. The young men and boys have a Lyceum, which not only learns us to speak in public but have subjects that are instructive.... Very seldom I missed one of my meetings; even when I lived out of town I attended pretty well and went home 7 miles at midnight. I feel the need of trying to learn as I am very bashful and awkward. AA? JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE "When I first commenced attending these meetings I used to dread for my turn to come. It seemed almost impossible for me to say anything at all—even if I knew it ever so well." One might go on endlessly, quoting bits of colorful detail, all of which would go to show that the Pioneers were happy, though their surroundings were hard, that they were reaching out for the good and yearning for the beautiful. 'They were gathered from all parts of the earth and brought with them different backgrounds of experience and culture. Bound by common ties of faith, and united in the common enterprise of conquering the desert, they built up a social and community life which was unique. Perhaps the most important factor in this was the fact that the religious leaders were also the leaders in temporal matters and the general directors of the recreation and leisure time activities. They worshiped together; they worked together; they played together, and by so doing were able to succeed in the face of great adversity. IMMORTAL PIONEER By Morris Olsen The sun that watched thy weary trek Has faded in the west; And even from the hand-carved post That marks thy place of rest, Time has erased the memory Of thy mortal name and deeds; And the little mound where flowers reposed Lies hidden in the weeds. Yet these are naught but symbols, Your sufferings were not in vain, For in the pattern of our lives Your spirit lives again. The trails you hewed through forests dense Where light was dimly shed, Still wind through our life's wilderness And show us where to tread. Sweets for the Persistent By Mabel Harmer HE State of Utah now boasts sugar factories with an enormous annual output and a payroll of many millions, but the story of the early attempts and struggles of the Pioneers to manufacture sugar, or anything resembling that greatly desired product, is a story of years of heartbreaking struggle. When the first settlers of the State wanted to raise wheat, they broke a few plows in the inhospitable ground, learned to soften it with water, and the worst of their struggles was over. 'The process of manufacturing cloth, from shearing the sheep to weaving on hand looms, was a lengthy one but not especially puzzling. The matter of sugar, however, was one that taxed the ingenuity and resources of the Pioneers to the utmost. They knew sugar to be almost a necessity from the standpoint of health besides being almost indispensable for the making of palatable foods, but where or how to get it remained one of their most difficult problems for almost two score years. Sugar brought in by ox team from the states cost over a dollar a pound, which made it all but prohibitive as a commodity for folk who seldom saw a dollar and couldn't very well afford to spend it for sugar when they did see it. Consequently they had to turn to every means within their power to make substitutes for sugar, hoping that some day they would learn how to manufacture the genuine article, which, after a series of heartbreaking attempts, they eventually accomplished. During the second summer in the valley, nearly everyone had a garden and some of nearly everything in those gardens was boiled down in an attempt to get "sweetening." Among the various agricultural products that were boiled down to make a crude sort of molasses or sorghum were beets, squash, carrots, cornstalks and melons. The product obtained served fairly well for some purposes but, naturally, could not take the place of sugar for culinary purposes or for table use. Nevertheless, the Pioneers accepted the results cheerfully until they could get something better. After three or four years of strictly home manufacture the art of molasses making was taken into factories, three being established for the purpose in 1851. Among those early manufacturers were Joseph Young, Burr Frost and William Freely, who advertised concerning their undertaking as follows: "Beet this who can! 'The undersigned would give notice to the citizens of Deseret that they are manufacturing molasses from the beet at Burr Frost's on Emigration street, one and a half blocks east of City Creek bridge. To all who have a surplus of beets, carrots or parsnips and will bring them to our molasses factory, well cleaned as for family use, we will make from them all the molasses we can and return the owners of the vegetables one-half of the molasses made. Those who are in want of sweetening and are disposed to encourage domestic manufacture will do well to call soon, as the earlier the vegetables are used, the better." The dark, gummy substance that AAA JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE was the result of this enterprise was so far from being satisfactory that efforts to manufacture sugar went on persistently. John Taylor, who was a leader in the search for sweets, attempted to make sugar out of corn. He put together a sort of crude apparatus to squeeze the corn stalk, made a boiler out of some stove piping and lumber, but he was forced to concede that the manufacture was not altogether a success. Early settlers down in Dixie during the early '6os learned that their warm climate would mature the Chinese sugar cane from which they produced a molasses that was superior to any made in the northern part of the territory. They found also, that by boiling it down to the limit they could obtain a sugar residue that would serve for some table purposes. Enterprising settlers in Box Elder and Provo also clutched at "sweet straws" in the hopes of obtaining something that could be converted into sugar. In the case of the former, the straws were the small box elder trees that grew in the vicinity, from which a sap was run off that produced a "specimen of beautifully clear and remarkably sweet and 'pleasant flavored syrup". A man who was familiar with the process of making sugar from the maple sap put forth his best efforts to get the same results from the box elder sap, but in the end had to be content with obtaining a fairly good confection. During one spring a sweet, sticky sap appeared on the leaves and twigs of trees in the city of Provo. The townspeople gathered the twigs, soaked them in water and boiled the sap thus obtained first to the syrup stage and then to sugar. It was said to have some resemblance to maple sugar, but the twigs and leaves had imparted a bitter taste and when a sample was sent to Brigham Young it is reported to have been received with no great enthusiasm. The Pioneers soon learned that the white sugar beet was the best source of molasses, and consequently the emigrants were urged to bring to Utah all the seed obtainable, which each family could plant with a view to making its own syrup and sugar. HE largest of the early molasses factories was that built in '51 by S. M. Blair of Texas and a Mr. Beach of St! Louis. The Mormon Church leaders were loud in their praises of this great enterprise but expressed the belief that it would not be possible for them to supply all the sweet that was needed in the community, and that if some expert manufacturers of sugar would appear upon the scene the citizens would be only too glad to surrender their efforts at home manufacture in their favor. They also expressed the wish that the presidents of the foreign missions would bend their efforts toward searching out such expert manufacturers and send them, together with the necessary equipment, to the Territory of Deseret. John Taylor, who was in charge of the French Mission at the time, acted upon this suggestion and organized the Deseret Manufacturing Company with a capital of $60,000. He purchased machinery and apparatus for the manufacture of sugar in Liverpool, at a cost of $12,500, had it shipped by boat to New Orleans where the U. S. Tax duties added another $5000 to the costly enterprise. From New Orleans the machinery was shipped up the river to Fort Leavenworth where it was loaded onto wagons and hauled by more than 200 ox teams over the plains to Salt Lake City at a labor and money cost that can only be imagined. For some unknown reason, the machinery was hauled on to Provo where in '52 the plant was assembled. Only now was the heartbreaking discovery made that the all important bone-cooking, sugar-clarifying retorts had not been shipped with the rest of the machinery. The promoters threw up their hands in despair upon learning that they had spent a fortune with no chance at making any immediate returns; but the Church authorities, having encouraged the enterprise, came to the rescue and bought the dubious assets of the Deseret Manufacturing Company. Later on the plant was moved to Sugar House—or what then became Sugar House—and an attempt was made to manufacture sugar. The attempt resulted only in more molasses and not too good a grade, at that. In fact, it was reported by some to be so sharp in flavor that "it would take the end of your tongue off". Brigham Young still had great hopes that the much needed sugar would soon be successfully manufactured, and at the spring conference in '53 he urged that the Saints generously plant sugar beets. In October of the same year a newspaper item made the statement, "We know that some were disappointed last fall in not getting sugar, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, JULY - 445 and some in getting poor molasses. But brethren, don't get discouraged; we have different workmen this year, and if we cannot give you sugar as you desire, no effort shall be wanting to give you good molasses. Bring your beets and try. Now is the time, at the old place before cold weather." It is hard indeed to record that these valiant efforts went for nothing and that after a sugar beet crop failure in '55 the venture was reluctantly given up. The pioneers of Utah were not the only ones, however, to experiment unsuccessfully with the manufacture of sugar. Between the years of 1838 and 1879 fourteen small sugar factories in states reaching from Maine to California went down to defeat in somewhat the same fashion, although none had gone to the tremendous amount of work to obtain machinery that the Mormon pioneers had done. Finally, in 1870 a Mr. Dyer erected a factory in California which by 79 was established on a profitable basis. By 1890 after more research and study two more factories were established in California. Others followed in '91 in Nebraska, and the same year the first successfully operated sugar factory in the Intermountain West began operations at Lehi, Utah, just forty years after the Pioneers had begun their persistent efforts to obtain sugar from the. White beets. The raising of sugar beets and the manufacture of sugar ranks today as one of the State's great industries with a total of fourteen factories and an annual payroll of millions of dollars. Hoops For Amanda By Martha Robeson Wright AMANDA STOPHER sat on the rough backless stool caressing the shimmering maroon silk that lay heaped before her on the crude table. She did not need a new dress for the party; her wedding gown would do. But Aunt Annie in New York had sent by Josiah Meddlebury, who had just come in from a hard trip across the plains, this belated wedding present, this mound of silk, glistening garnet in the early autumn sunshine that poured through the open door and the small square hole in the east wall which served as a window. Just having the goods would have made the longing to sew begin tugging at Amanda's fingers. But there had been included in the package a new magazine called Harper's that showed the latest fashions. Amanda's mother had always cut the patterns for her clothes, but it was high time Amanda tried it herself. Her grandmother's sewing chest that had been given her for a wedding present had the top tray filled with notions, even three precious needles and a silver thimble that was older than the chest; but she knew it would be necessary to. Ravel some of the silk to get thread to match. Amanda's hands gently patted the beautiful fabric. 'They had never had anything like this, even in Nauvoo, where her father had owned a fine brick house right near the Prophet's and they had good furniture and lots of books which they had brought with them from Tennessee. In Brown's Fort, or Ogden as it was now Called, dresses had to last a long time because the piece goods was hand loomed after the spinning was done, unless it was sent by your well-to-do relatives who thought your folks plain crazy for leaving comfort and security to come out to a wilderness full of savages and wild animals. The girl gathered the soft material into her arms and went to the round mirror that hung on the wall above a short wash bench. "It does become you," she murmured, holding the goods close to her face. "It makes your hair and eyes look browner and shinier." She tilted her head this way and that like a small bird looking at its reflection in a pool. "I could make it up in three weeks. For your first dance since you and John were married, Mrs. Stopher." Amanda returned the silk to the table and took up the new magazine. She reckoned she could look just as pretty in those hoop skirts as those ladies who smirked at her from its pages. She could get her waist that little, too, with proper stays; it would not be hard to do either, as her waist was not so very big in the first place. It would not be such a chore to fix her hair that way when it was naturally curly. But how could she get the hoops in time for the party? Had she been at home it would have been a simple matter to have mentioned it to her father who would have patted her cheek or pinched her chin and got her hoops from somewhere. But a married woman of sixteen gets her money and clothing from her husband. If he had no money, he bartered things for his family's needs. John would never think of doing any trading for a set of hoops for a woman's dress. Judge Gerard would think it clever and womanly to want such flipperies, but John would never understand. His people had been very poor pioneers who had come across the plains suffering great hardships for want of food and clothing, and while some of them might have longed for luxuries, they would never dream of getting them for this wilderness life. Of course, she was lucky in having a father better fixed than most of the settlers, one who had tools and supplies and read the law; but she was married and had to abide by her husband's ideas. AMANDA liked being married to John, but it was sort of a comedown to be living in the old granary, especially when Mary Anne Davison made slighting remarks. Mary Anne's father was almost as well-to-do as Judge Gerard, and Mary Anne was just the kind who, though she knew they were only living there until next fall, would start something. John was going to build their cabin the next fall, and he was proud of living in the granary because it meant he did not need help. John had been like that when he had asked Amanda's father for permission to marry her. She had wanted to go with him into the small office in front of their home, but John said he did not need a woman's support. Listening outside the lightly closed door, she had heard her father say, "You're a fine boy, John. Got good blood in you. If Amanda loves you I reckon you have my blessing. But I thought it was Mary Anne you were sweet on." "No, sir. I went dancing some RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, JULY - 447 with Mary Anne, but Amanda—well —she's like a young deer, her head held high and her soft eyes." How beautiful John could talk sometimes. Amanda's listening heart swelled with pride and love. "She's young, John. We've kinda petted her some, bein' she's the baby, but she's sweet and a good girl. She's inclined to be flighty and headstrong sometimes like women will, but she'll settle down if you keep a loose rein on her at first till she gets used to things. How about me building you a house near us here?" "No, sir, thank you." Amanda could almost see John standing proud and straight as an Indian— maybe flinging back that long lock of fair hair away from his eyes with a backward flick of his head. "You see the folks have an old granary near my fields, not so far from Rader's store. It's stout and warm, and I'll cut a winda in the east wall and build a good chimney. I aim to build my own cabin next year after the crops get done." "You seem to know what you want to do, my boy," Judge Gerard said. "I admire your spirit, and you'll make Mandy a good husband." Amanda brought her mind back to her present surroundings and glanced about the granary where she now lived with John. He had built a good-drawing fireplace where now a kettle hung, its contents bubbling and simmering. On the rock hearth stood an iron spider on which Amanda did all her other cooking. Against the north wall was built a crude cupboard, while beside the west wall stood her spool bed that her mother had insisted she take; it had been brought all the way from Tennessee along with the round mirror that JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE hung above the wash bench. The two crude stools and the rough table completed furnishings of the log hut. It was snug and warm as John had said, and someday John would get her a stove like her folks had owned in Missouri. "If I can get those hoops I'll show Mary Anne." Amanda took a wooden spoon and stirred the stew, then added a bit of water with a gourd dipper. "I'll go ask Mr. Rader about them. He might get some from the freight wagons coming through Salt Lake soon. Mr. Rader said he was going to Salt Lake the next day, and would try to make a deal. "But don't tell anybody," pleaded Amanda, "I want to be the first to wear them. How much do you think they'll cost?". "I should jedge about five dollars." The room seemed to spin around her. Five dollars! She could never get that much money. But she had come into the store and told Mr. Rader she wanted the hoops and hadn't asked the price first, so she could not back out now. "You go ahead and sec if you can get them, please," she said hurriedly. HEN she reached home again Amanda once more sat on the little stool and studied the pictures in the magazine. Even if she didn't get the hoops, the dress would stand out nicely if she made it right full and wore her petticoats. If Mr. Rader was able to get the hoops and she did not take them he would probably sell them to Mary Anne, and then Mary Anne's nose would go a little farther into the air. Amanda glanced at the sun. John would soon be home for dinner. She went to the cupboard and took out a tablecloth, knives and forks. That was one thing she was glad she had— two nice tablecloths to make them remember their manners. The two plates, cups, and slices of bread. And butter were on the table when John came in. "Well, who's this in my house? Haven't I seen you somewhere before?" John looked at her with assumed surprise, as he always did; and Amanda giggled and replied, as she always did, "Your face does look familiar, sir." She dropped him a curtsy. "Mandy, Mandy!" He gathered her in his arms. "John," Amanda began, as John released her, "Josiah Meddlebury stopped here and left me some goods. It's from Aunt Annie in New York for a wedding present to me." She carefully lifted the silk out of the chest where she had placed it before setting the table. John fingered the edge of it with his rough fingers. "It surely is fine," he said slowly. "Won't it be beautiful for the dance? I can make it up in three weeks." "You got your wedding dress." "Oh, no," she said hastily, "it would spoil it to wear it to anything but a wedding." He looked down at her. "You mean you're savin' it for your next husband?" "Oh, John, don't tease me. You know what I mean. It was Mother's wedding dress, too, and I want it saved for special things. This goods will be wonderful made up, and it was given to me." "A thrifty wife," John laughed and swung her into the air. Maybe she was spoiled, as her grandmother had often told her, but was it so awful to be selfish enough to want to make your husband proud of you? John would be proud, too. He might not say so, but his head would be helda little straighter as he walked into the dance beside her in the billowed skirts that would gently sway. Mary Anne with her critical airs would be so envious. Amanda sewed during every spare minute. She was not worried about getting the hoops. She had always had what she wanted, and something would turn up. Eagerly she measured her small waist after she had fixed the stays. Eighteen inches! She would have the smallest waist at the party, and the hoops would make it look smaller yet. 'WO days before the dance John came in with a five gallon keg of molasses which he set in the east corner. "Your father gave me this." John was pleased, for sweets were very scarce and needful. Judge Gerard had made the molasses and given John part of it. "More'n we could use at once so I told Carl Jenson he could have a couple of gallons for helping me with the corn. His folks've had no sweets for weeks." "They'll like this." "Have I seen you somewhere before?" John asked and kissed _ her. She gave him a squeeze and giggled, "Your face looks familiar, sir." '"How's the dress? Done?" "You'll see it the day of the dance, and you'll get a surprise." "Got to get back, Mandy. Want to get through 'fore sundown. Pesky RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, JULY - 449 Indians been stealing corn again. Keep the door shut." John had just gone when Mr. Rader sent his son Willie over to tell her that he'd returned from his trip and had the hoops. "Tell your father I'll be over tomorrow, Willie." That night she lay beside John wondering what to do. He slept soundly, but her eyes would not close. If she only knew of some way to make John understand how much those hoops meant to her. But he wouldn't see the need of trading good corn, wheat or vegetables for hoops. Then she thought of the keg of molasses standing in the corner. Her father would not have given it to John if she was not his wife. Why couldn't she take half the molasses to Mr. Rader to pay for the hoops? Father had more molasses, and he always gave her what she asked for, so he would think nothing of it. The next morning John was out earlier than usual, for Carl was helping him finish up in time to rest a little before the dance. As soon as he was gone, Amanda rushed over to Mr. Rader's who stood smiling and cheerful beside the counter. "You want to buy some molasses?" she asked, breathless from her hurried walk. His eyes peered at her through his spectacles. '""Wal, I might. Your father bein' the only one makin' it you must have some o'his'n." "He gave me more than we need. I can sell you half—for the hoops. You can make a good profit." Mr. Rader nodded his head solemnly though his eyes twinkled. "If I didn't hev tuh pay too much fer it. Can't stock up too much on produce 450 - JULY, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE fer em, an' cash money's as scarce as sweets." "How much could you give me?" "Wall, les see. A dollar a gallon?" A dollar a gallon!" Her half of the keg would amount to only two dollars and a half, not enough to buy the hoops. If she could sell the whole five gallons! Father would give John some more. Mr. Rader saw the hesitancy in her eyes and hurriedly opened the box. "Funny lookin' contraptions, ain't they?" "B-but I—I. Only had two and a half gallons to sell," Amanda explained. "It isn't enough." Mr. Rader's face fell. "I'd hafta get five dollars fer 'em. An' then I| ain't makin' a mite o' profit, jest accomodatin' yuh. Got somethin' else?" The whole keg would make the five dollars! John could pay Carl with something else, and her father would give them more molasses. Mr. Rader's smile was beginning to look set. If she didn't take the hoops after all the trouble he had gone to, she knew the community would soon know about it. "W-would you take all the five gallons for the hoops?" she asked. Mr. Rader rubbed his hands together and chuckled, "Yup, I'll get Willie tu take the hoops over fer yuh, and he can bring back the molasses." T HOME she shoved the box under the bed. She would put on the new dress before John got home. If she looked pretty he wouldn't think about the molasses, and even if he did he would be in better humor. Because there was to be a big supper given at the dance she and John wouldn't eat very much before they went. She straightened the house, slid the shutter across the window and bolted the door before she took her bath before the fire. She wet her hair jet enough to set the curls. After the hoops were adjusted she slipped the dress over her head. Her hair was dressed with waves on each side of the center part and curls hanging to her shoulders in the back but pinned up by her ears on the sides. She was glad she had the mirror even if it only showed her from the waist up, though she could get a glimpse of where the hoops began to swell around her hips. She looked pretty in maroon. Amanda looked down at her feet. They seemed almost as small as the ones in the magazine. 'hen she remembered to take John's suit from the chest and hang it on a peg to get the wrinkles out. She hugged the coat. John was coming up the hard clay path. With a final pat to her curls she posed in the center of the room, waiting. John opened the door, and his face lighted as he saw her there, slowly and gracefully turning before him. "My, my, woman, what are you doing here?"; Amanda stopped in front of him and curtsied. John's face assumed that puzzled expression. "Haven't I seen you somewhere before?" "You're face looks familiar, sir,' Amanda replied and kissed him. '"What's under that skirt?" he asked. "Hoops. Like it?" She raised the skirt to show the bottom hoops. "It's the newest style." This is the place where deeds are done, This is the place in sage and love and religious fervor are usually faster if the mood contains joy, slower if it contains sorrow. Passive moods
B. Dynamics:
1. Less intense emotion of any kind may be expressed either by extreme loudness or extreme softness. Intense emotions call for medium loudness or medium softness.
2. In songs, the sentence structure partially controls the finer shading. Nouns, pronouns, adjectives, adverbs and verbs are sung louder than conjunctions and prepositions. The most important word of the sentence or phrase is usually sung loudest, preceded by a crescendo and followed by a diminuendo.
3. The accented syllables of a word are sung louder than unaccented ones.
4. The musical phrase usually consists of 4 (sometimes 2) measures, with a point of rest at the end. It should be treated in one or more of the following ways: a. It may be louder in the middle and softer at both ends, or vice versa. b. When the melody goes up, sing louder, when it goes down, softer. c. A very long note should not usually be the same loudness throughout. d. When a phrase or section is repeated, do not do it the same way both times. The words will usually determine which to do.
IV. Projection of the Mood to the Singers: A. A large beat goes with a slow tempo, a small one with a fast tempo.
1. Tempo changes can be indicated by changing both size and speed, either gradually or suddenly. Change of speed alone is not enough.
B. When tempo remains the same, a large beat indicates loudness, a small one softness.
1. Dynamics changes can be indicated by changing the size of the beat, keeping its speed constant.
2. Intensity of any type of emotion can be communicated to the singers by tensing the muscles of the entire body.
C. Attack, Release, Accent, Change in speed - In these, the motions of the left hand parallel those of the right.
D. Think of the emotion to be expressed. This will result in appropriate facial expression, which is the most effective of all means of projecting mood.
E. The left hand is used always for emphasis. When raised, it attracts attention. Therefore, it should be used only when needed, and relaxed at the side the rest of the time. These are uses of the left hand: a. Soft, palm down b. Louder, palm up c. Loudest, doubled fist. Intensity of emotion is expressed by tension in the muscles of the hand and arm. d. Special indications to individual parts, accomplished by pointing at the section involved at the proper time. e. Change in dynamics.
F. Breathing pauses can be indicated by taking a breath in such a way that the singers can do it with you.

LESSON PREVIEW 1939-40
Theology and Testimony MINISTRY OF THE EARLY APOSTLES
The course in Theology for the year 1939-40 is to be a continuation of the New Testament, containing further information about the "Ministry of The Early Apostles," their personalities and lives. We feel sure the lessons will be inspiring and helpful to all those who study them, for great effort has been taken in their preparation; much research and exhaustive reading have been necessary. The lessons on John the Beloved, Matthew the Publican and Paul the Missionary are especially colorful and interesting. Such a course carefully studied will enrich the lives of all who have the privilege of taking it. It forms a foundation for character building, for a better understanding of human relations, and a greater appreciation of everything worth while in life's experience.
Following are the lesson titles:
1. John the Beloved.
2. John the Beloved (Cont'd.).
3. Matthew the Publican.
4. Saul the Pharisee and Persecutor.
5. Saul's Vision and the Changed Life.
6. Paul the Missionary.
7. Paul the Missionary (Cont'd.).
8. Paul the Writer.
9. Paul's Lasting Influence.

Literary Department THE ADVANCE OF THE NOVEL
The Literary study for 1939-40 is a continuation of "The Advance of the Novel," with the same objectives as stated at the beginning of the course: To trace the novel from its beginning and show the dominant position it holds in the field of literature today; to develop taste and judgment in selecting from the very extensive number of books available; to exercise literary guidance and to help interpret some of the masterpieces of fiction.
The Advance of the English Novel by William Lyon Phelps will still be found a stimulating and delightful reference book. The Story of the World's Literature by John Macy will be used as a reference. This book was purchased by the stakes and wards for use in the 1933-4 Literary course, "Life and Literature". It should have been preserved and will be found very useful in the present course.
Three great novels will be studied and can be obtained at the Deseret Book Store after July 1, 1939: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc—Mark Twain............$1.75 Les Miserables—Victor Hugo.....1.00 The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse—Blasco Ibanez.....1.00 The Story of the World's Literature—John Macy.........75
Social Service Psychology and Modern Problems
The aim of the Social Service lessons for the coming year is to apply psychology to the problems with which every mature person is faced in an ever changing world today. If we are to conduct ourselves wisely in meeting the rapidly changing daily scene, we need most of all to understand ourselves and each other. The world is a troubled one today, not because we lack control over the forces of nature, but because we do not fully understand ourselves and each other. The course for the coming year is designed to broaden our understanding of human nature and thereby to contribute to happy living.
The following lesson titles indicate the scope of the subject matter to be presented:
1. How Does Propaganda Affect Me?
2. Psychology of Fads, Crazes, and Fashions.
3. How Shall I Conduct Myself in an Age of Automobiles?
4. Psychology of Resisting Sales Pressure.
5. How to Sell the Gospel.
6. Psychology of Personal Efficiency.
7. Superstition or Reason—Which Shall I Follow?
8. Psychology of Happy Living.
No Social Service lesson or lesson in Family Relationships is planned for December.
Mission Lessons L. D. S. Church History (To be used on Literary day)
This is a course in the history of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. It does not aim to include the teachings or doctrines of the Church, except incidentally, as they are associated with the historical events. Before an idea can properly be understood, something must be known of the conditions under which it was received, something about the person or persons to whom it was given, and something about the way it was developed and applied in human life. It is the purpose of the present course to give these preliminary matters. Most of this material is in the form of narrative, incident, story, and is for this reason exceedingly interesting and understandable. In association with this history are some poems and songs composed under the spirit of the Restored Gospel. It is hoped that these will add to both the information and the enjoyment of those who take this course. The poems may be memorized, discussed in the class, and the songs sung, as the teacher may see fit. In every case, however, they grew out of the situation treated in the lesson in which they appear.
There can be no question as to the importance of such a course. The revelations given to the Prophet Joseph Smith were intended for those who live in this Dispensation, just as the Bible was intended for the Christian and the pre-Christian Dispensation and the Book of Mormon for the peoples who lived on the American continents anciently. Joseph Smith is pre-eminently our prophet, and he is so in exactly the same sense that Isaiah was an Hebraic prophet, Alma the Elder a prophet to the Nephites, and Mahonri the prophet of the Jaredites. Since this is so, it should follow that nothing can be of greater importance to our generation than to know how God has manifested himself to us in this age of the world. As God adapted his revelations to the Hebrews and to the peoples of the Book of Mormon, so he has adapted his revelations to us. And the following lessons are the history of how that was done:
1. The First Vision.
2. Cumorah and the Book.
3. The Ancient Plates.
4. Our Book of Mormon.
5. Witnesses.
6. Organization of the Church.
7. Early Growth of the Church.
8. The Church Moves West.
9. Events in Missouri.
Education for Family Life FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS
In harmony with the wishes of members of the classes in Education for Family Life as expressed by stake presidents at our recent April Conference, we shall continue our lessons in Family Relationships during the year 1939-40. The theme for the basis of our discussions shall be "My Home is My Refuge". It shall be our aim to make the lessons as practical, as stimulating, and as interesting as possible. In planning the lessons we shall keep in mind particularly the needs of our young parents, those who have more recently assumed the responsibilities of founding a home and of rearing a family. In our discussions we shall consider the family as "a unity of interacting personalities," thus emphasizing the great importance and the high value of the human relationship factor in family life.

If there's a thing I long for In this old hectic life, It is to keep my soul at peace Through all the toil and strife.
