Family Relations Department Kate M. Barker, Chairman
PURPOSE AND CONDUCT OF COURSE IN "EDUCATION FOR FAMILY LIFE" By Nellie O. Parker
THE course "Education For Family Life" was launched one year ago. While it has not been the entire success we wished it to be, there have been some very gratifying results. We feel that in many cases the aim of the course has not been clearly understood, and difficulties have arisen that need not have been; for example, the conflict with the social service lesson and its class leader. It was never intended that this course conflict with or detract from the social service lesson. The Relief Society program has always been planned to meet the needs and interests of the women and has been expanded to embrace new things as progress in a changing world has demanded. We find that we are not reaching all eligible Latter-day Saint women through our regular courses of study. We are not getting all of our young mothers, many of whom are high school and college graduates. Many of these young women are joining clubs and study groups to the exclusion of Relief Society. To meet this situation, the very popular subject of "Education For Family Life" was chosen as the new course of study. The class procedure was so planned as to give as many opportunities as possible for personal participation and development of leadership ability. Family relations is a very vital and timely subject. Current books and magazines abound with excellent thoughts and discussions concerning it. It is an important subject for everyone, especially parents. It assists them in aiding the family to function as it should, to build character and develop responsible citizens, to make better and happier homes and communities, and to build a true democracy. It is recommended that the course be held on the fourth Tuesday of each month and that it run simultaneously with the social service lesson but not draw from the social service class. It is the consensus of the General Board that if it is impossible to hold the class at this time because of the inconvenience to mothers with young children, another hour be chosen that will allow these women the privilege of attending. The class is not to be held on any of the other Tuesdays; we suggest that four P. M. on the fourth Tuesday may permit mothers to secure older children, home from school, to care for the babies. An evening hour, or Sunday evening after church, may be an advantageous time. It would be convenient for fathers to attend if the classes were held in the evening. An officer of Relief Society should meet with the class; this should not be too great a burden as the class meets but once each month. The class is to be recruited mainly from new women. Seek out and invite all women who should be inter-
766 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
ested in the course and who would enjoy taking an active part either as class leader or giving topics and otherwise participating in the discussion. The class should be a means of adding new members to the Relief Society organization. In conformity with our aim, we suggest that the class be allowed as much opportunity for personal initiative and activity as possible within Relief Society regulations and standards. Use your best judgment in guiding the course. It is to be under the supervision of the counselor in charge of education. It is recommended that a committee of three be chosen, with one member as chairman, to serve as program committee, to manage programs and to arrange for those taking part each month. If there is difficulty in securing a different class leader for each lesson, members of the program committee themselves may take turns being class leader, giving other members assignments and allowing considerable time for discussing and solving the family relationship problems. There should be a department in Union meeting to instruct and guide leaders in planning, organizing, and presenting the lesson material. There should be open sessions occasionally to which husbands are invited and opportunity given them to participate in the discussion.
HINTS AND AIDS FOR TEACHING FAMILY RELATIONS By Caroline M. Hendricks
THIS morning I shall discuss three points with regard to the Family Relations class: First, what we are hoping to do—our aim in this department; second, some of the fundamental characteristics of a leader in Family Relations; third, the material in the lessons. In teaching Family Relations, please do not hope to tell people how they can be happy. There is no recipe for happy family life, there is no panacea; all we can hope to do is to help each other to see our problems and analyze them with a degree of intelligent understanding. Family relations is one of the most difficult subjects to teach; yet, it is one of the most satisfactory subjects. Do not attempt to use the number of members in your class as a criterion of your success. If during the entire year you can help one family, you are justified in feeling that your time and efforts have been very well spent. It is worth while for parents to come together and discuss their problems if they do nothing more than learn that their family is not unique in its problems. As long as we have family life, we will have problems to solve, and fundamentally these problems are the same. They differ in degree. One family may have a problem that is more serious than that of someone else in one respect, but the other person will have another problem that seems to balance it. We all have problems, and we always will have problems; what we are attempting to do is to
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 767
help people get an intelligent understanding of family relationships so that they will be able to solve their problems more satisfactorily. You have already heard that class discussion is the most desirable method of handling this subject matter. Encourage members to talk over their problems, but never let them feel that you realize they are talking about their own family problems, even if you know they are. Make discussion absolutely impersonal. You must be careful in the example cases discussed not to betray the confidence of people who probably have come to you to talk over their problems. Be sincere in your work, have faith in family life. Feel in your hearts that the greatest happiness in this world comes from human relationships and that the most important human relationships are those within the family group. Help your class members to realize that the greatest source of happiness and satisfaction in this life comes from satisfactory family relationships. Be vitally interested in your subject. Are you interested in family life? Are you interested in gaining information about it—the best information available? I would suggest that during the winter at least two good books dealing with the family be read. Do not depend entirely upon the material contained in the lesson. Such an important subject as Family Relations requires more information than can possibly be given in the space devoted to these lessons in the Magazine. This material will serve, I hope, to stimulate you; then, you must do research work. If you can make the members of your class feel that you have a fund of information back of what you are saying, it will inspire confidence in you and add greatly to your success. It is essential that any person who serves in the capacity of a leader in family life inspires confidence in people. E. R. Groves' book The American Family, is worthy of your consideration. Groves says that home is not a place, it is a habit of life, and some people have this habit, of course, more fully than do others. What we call "domesticity" is a habit that has come forth from associations in our former family experience. If we have this habit of home, this habit of domesticity, we have it as a result of our earlier life. Domestic experience is not attained by the power of the will but it must come through experience and growth. Help these young mothers, these young married people, to realize that we all have problems when we start out, and that living together in the family is simply an experience; emphasize the fact that there can be no happiness without growth and development. Help them to appreciate the seriousness of domestic failure; it influences throughout life every person who is a part of that family group. I cannot tell you where you can find well written material on the first lesson, which deals with the family council, but I do know of many families who have practiced the family council plan, and it has been their salvation. I hope you will discuss the importance of coming together in family life and its value in binding people together within the family. Use your own ideas and your own initiative and
768 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
work them into the ideas contained in the outlined lessons. The second lesson deals with the handling of family finances. Stress the point that whatever plan the family decides upon must be agreeable to both mates. There must be agreement as to the handling of family finances. I wish to stress again the importance of faith in family life as the foundation of success in your work. Our major aim is to make the home a refuge, a place of peace and comfort where every individual has security, love and affection; a place where those who are weary and tired after the day's work will find peace and rest. "It is not life that matters," says Hornell Hart, "it is the courage you bring to it." There is no problem that is too difficult for the individual if that individual has the necessary courage with which to meet that problem. This is the message we have for our young people who are beginning to found their homes during this very difficult period of time.
Officers Meeting
ADDRESS By William E. Ryberg Member of Church Welfare Committee
I SINCERELY appreciate the honor of representing the Church Welfare Committee at this meeting. As long as I can remember, one of the most impressive things in my life, and one from which I received great inspiration, was the work of Relief Society as expressed in my own mother. I well remember that through the most depressing periods of our early life a consoling thing which seemed to hold our family together was the great confidence and the firm testimony of my mother in the truth of the church to which we belonged, and I am confident this testimony was largely influenced by her activities in Relief Society. When my mother approached her eightieth birthday, she was still in the service of Relief Society, still making her calls in the district allotted to her. I recognize that today I am speaking to a group of sisters to whom Church Welfare is not at all new. The fundamental principles of the Relief Society, as I understand them, are exactly the ideals which Church Welfare is attempting to put into actual practice. If there is anything new to Church Welfare, which the Relief Society does not understand, it can only be that their service has been augmented by the service of certain brethren who have been called to assist in solving the economic problems and the distress of those who are unfortunate in a period of time when conditions are too serious for any one unit of the Church to handle alone.
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 769
Sister Robison has asked what the Relief Society can do, as a body, to further the plans of the Church Welfare Program. I am thoroughly convinced that without the assistance of Relief Society, the Church Welfare Program cannot be successfully consummated. There is no organization in the Church which has the ability and which has had the experience in relief work that the Relief Society has had. The Relief Society does not only hold and maintain the admiration, respect, love and esteem of members of the Church, but throughout the world the influence of this organization is known. Therefore, there is no question in my mind but that the ultimate success of the Church Welfare Program will be measured in terms of the amount of activity into which the leaders of the Church bring the Relief Society. A very important factor in the success of the Program, and one, I believe, that lies directly within the hands of the members of the Relief Society, is the influence of women. If we were to analyze the underlying reasons for the success of men who have contributed to the world in the fields of science, literature, social service, or any phase of public life, we would find somewhere the inspiration of a splendid woman. In the totalitarian or dictatorship countries, the influence of womanhood is not present, while in the democracies, the place of women in the affairs of the state is almost equal to that of men. Men should recognize the influence for good exerted by women. I believe the Relief Society can influence the brethren to fulfill their obligations as members of the Priesthood. There are many of us who are willing to accept high positions of honor and responsibility in the Church without accepting the actual work and effort which go with these honors. A man who accepts a position of responsibility and honor and who does not fulfill the obligations of that honor is not only unfaithful to the Church but is unfaithful to that woman whom he admires most and also to himself. One of our first considerations should be the temporal welfare of our less fortunate brethren. I do not think it is quite consistent for our Church to pose as the spiritual savior of mankind if it cannot, here in this world, help in the temporal salvation of the less fortunate. Remember, sisters, there is no other place in all the world which is as blessed as is our own country. We should be grateful that we live in a country which is so blessed. The majority of Church members are not more than three generations away from the war-torn European countries, and the Gospel message is the thing that brought our grandparents here. Is it then too much that you sisters use your influence to help the brethren appreciate the blessings and recognize the obligations which are theirs as members of this Church? Before I close, I want to answer two other questions that were propounded to me: What can the Relief Society do in furnishing supplies from the efforts of their own auxiliary organization for the Church Welfare Program, and how may credits be received? In the first instance, the Relief Society presidency of any ward should contact the bishop and dis-
770 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
cuss with him first of all what articles are required in that particular ward, or what that particular ward might profitably contribute to the stake, and from the stake to the region. If the Relief Society in that ward has surplus commodities of any type, which are also surplus in the stake, there is no reason why these cannot be contributed to the region. There is no reason why that particular Relief Society cannot receive credit for that contribution, and there is no reason why they should not draw from the region other needed articles up to the amount of the credit. The other question is: How can Relief Society develop new projects in their own local ward units, and from what source can the money be obtained? The Relief Society stake president knows, or should know, the things which are surplus in the region, and the things which the region is in need of. In the event a program is developed in a stake or ward to supply these shortages, the funds naturally come from the bishop. The bishop can in turn take his funds from the fast offerings. In the event the fast offerings in his ward are not sufficient for this purpose, he has the right to request funds from the stake fast offerings. In the event the fast offerings from the stake are not sufficient, he has the right to request funds from the region. I think it is purely within the right of the president of a local unit to inform her bishop if she knows of any worthy members of the Church within her ward who are suffering. I think if the Bishop does not respond after the information is given to him, she should report the condition to her stake president. If it is not then corrected, the stake president should report it to a higher source. It is not human, it is inhuman, to allow people to suffer, and I think it is definitely the responsibility of the Relief Society to see that no such conditions occur. The following statement was made to me at the close of a certain meeting: "Brother Ryberg, I know that I can get assistance from the ward if I only dared ask, but I would rather be put against a wall and shot than to go through the humiliation that I would have to go through in order to get that assistance. My business would immediately become the business of the entire ward." That is tragic, sisters, and I have enough confidence in the rank and file of the Relief Society to believe that such situations exist only in a minority of cases. When a member of the Church comes to any person with authority in the Church and confesses the problems which are bearing him down, the information given is confidential, and the person who gives it has the right to expect that it will be kept in strictest confidence. The question has been asked: What part does the Relief Society play with reference to the Priesthood? Every Friday morning the General Committee meets with the First Presidency, a representative of the Presiding Bishopric, a representative of the Council of the Twelve, a representative of the First Council of Seventy, and a representative of the General Board of Relief Society. No step is taken in the Church Welfare Program, as related to the Relief
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 771
Society, without the General Board first being consulted. Now that should hold true throughout the entire Program. There is a definite place for the Relief Society in the ward set-up, in the stake set-up, and in the regional set-up. If the First Presidency, the Presiding Bishopric, the Council of the Twelve, the First Council of Seventy and the General Committee feel that the advice and counsel of the sisters of the General Board is necessary, surely the ward units and stake units should recognize that fact in their deliberations. If there is any place in a ward, stake or region in the Church where this is being overlooked, I am of the opinion that the Church Welfare Program is not particularly successful. In the event this condition exists in your stake or ward, you sisters holding responsible positions should report it to your stake president, and failing there, to your general officers. When it is reported to them, I am sure they will report it at the council meeting on Friday morning. I am happy to have been with you this morning, and have attempted to explain some things which seem to have been in question.
OFFICIAL INSTRUCTIONS By President Louise Y. Robison
WE are very happy to meet with you this morning under such favorable conditions, to discuss problems of common interest. New Books: I should like to call your attention to some new books which are of special interest to Latter-day Saints. Brother George D. Pyper has just published a volume entitled The Story of Our Hymns, which presents in his delightful style the stories of our Latter-day Saint hymns. Sister Janet Bingham Dee of the Primary General Board has published a valuable and beautifully illustrated book, A Voice From The Dust, which presents the story and doctrine contained in the Book of Mormon in a form easily read. This publication should result in a greater understanding of the Book of Mormon. We unhesitatingly recommend both books to you. The Relief Society Song Book will soon be ready. It will be a handy, loose-leaf style so that when open it will lie perfectly flat. The words and music are photographic, making it very easily read. We are striving to keep the price of the book as low as possible. The stakes will be notified as soon as the book is ready. Last year some very excellent novels were used in our Literature course. The Deseret Book Company still has a number of these books on hand, which can be purchased at a nominal price. We suggest them as very appropriate Christmas gifts. Pre-natal Care: There are still women in our Society who do not know where to obtain information on pre-natal care. Splendid material may be secured by writing to your state board of health. Stake presidents kindly notify the sisters. Child Health: We have a great
772 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
responsibility in safeguarding the health of our children. Children with weak bodies grow up greatly handicapped. In a school district within one hundred miles of Salt Lake City, an examination of 338 pre-school children revealed only 78 with teeth in normal condition— these, of course, were baby teeth. An examination of 476 sixth-grade children—an eleven-year-old group with permanent teeth—revealed only 60 with teeth in good condition. The other day I heard of a man who earns $180 per month. An examination of the teeth of his five children revealed that each child had more than five cavities. The proper care of children's teeth may well be a project for Relief Society. This does not mean we are to pay for the dental care of all children, but rather that we impress mothers with the importance of good teeth and stimulate them to make use of the opportunities available to have teeth examined and properly cared for. Of course, there are families in the Church who have difficulty in supplying the basic necessities of life for children, and for this reason teeth are neglected. In such cases, tide them over. Let them feel it is their responsibility as far as possible to carry the expense of corrective work, but arrange for them to pay a little down and meet the balance as they best can. Where families positively cannot meet the expense themselves and where the ward and stake are unable to do so, call on the General Board. This problem is of sufficient importance to attract community interest. I believe there are doctors, city and county commissioners, and other groups who would aid in this important welfare program. Children must not go through life handicapped because of the small amount of money necessary to insure good teeth. Relief Society Funds and The Ward Budget: The Presiding Bishopric have instituted ward budgets throughout the Church. The Relief Society heartily approves of the principle of the budget. The budget plan has been clearly set forth in the August, 1939, issue of Progress of the Church, published by the Presiding Bishopric and sent to all bishops. We suggest that Relief Society presidents ask the bishops to permit them to read this. Due to the nature of Relief Society work, it is deemed advisable that there be certain modifications in the application of the budget plan with regard to Relief Society funds. The charity fund is not included in the budget. This fund is created from collections received by the visiting teachers and is used only for the purpose indicated by its name. Membership dues are not included; we believe that when women make the effort to pay their own annual dues they appreciate their membership more. The general fund, which is a contingent or operating fund of the Organization, has in the past been created by the industry of the women. It has been used for the purchase of textbooks, record books and miscellaneous things. Now, in wards operating on the budget plan, the general fund may be allowed Relief Society from the ward budget, just as other auxiliaries receive their operating fund. To determine the amount necessary, we recommend
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 773
that expenses incurred during the past three years be averaged and the amount of this average be requested of the bishop when the ward budget is set up. Do not draw on the bishopric for any more than is absolutely necessary. If you have available funds, use these before drawing on the ward budget. These rulings may change in the future, but for the present this is our plan. Even though a ward is on a budget, we can see no reason why Relief Society should not hold a bazaar to display useful handmade articles and to encourage people to make beautiful things. We cannot see any possible objection to the sale of these articles, but there should be no admission fee charged. We trust Relief Society will do everything within its power to aid the bishop in making the budget plan succeed. Relief Society Singing Mothers: The question has been asked whether the Relief Society Singing Mothers from all over the Church will again be invited to sing at April Conference, 1940. The plan now is to concentrate efforts on a glorious centennial in 1942. So we ask the Singing Mothers to perfect themselves and sing in the stakes and wards, but the Augmented Chorus will not be assembled again until 1942. We hope that by next April we will be prepared to announce the details of the program for our hundredth anniversary. Family Relations: Sound family relationships are of vital importance. The course "Education for Family Life" has been introduced into the Relief Society program to help young mothers better understand and meet the problems of family life. Magazine Drive: We are delighted with the work of our Magazine representatives. Most of the stakes are now engaged in the Drive and excellent results are being obtained. Do not feel that people are too poor to subscribe; those who have the least money are in many cases our most faithful subscribers. Class Leaders: Before calling any person to a position in Relief Society, in either ward or stake capacity, advise her of the full requirements of the position. Attendance of class leaders at Union meeting is almost a necessity. There may occasionally be a woman who is able to render fine service to Relief Society and thus tie herself to the Church, yet, because of being in school or at business, is unable to attend Union meeting. Such cases, however, are rare. Before asking women to accept positions, ask them if they have time to attend Union meeting. Church Beautification: Church beautification, and that also includes home beautification, can be carried out better with the women interested than in any other way. Encourage the sisters to plant gardens, shrubs and trees. A fine practice is to plant a tree in honor of a birthday or some other important event. I heard an Idaho man say that the thing which made him want to go back to his home in the East was a great big oak tree that had been planted in his honor when he was born. That tree tied him to the East even more than did the people. There is sentiment in tree planting. Encourage the sisters to see that ward chapels are kept clean, that
774 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
children are taught not to throw papers and other things about meeting house grounds. Nutrition: The following question has been asked: "Is the nutrition class, held on Work and Business day, optional with the wards?" We refer you to the following ruling in the May, 1938, issue of the Relief Society Magazine, page 334: "The General Board suggests that the use of this material (nutrition) be optional in the wards and may be used in connection with the traditional activities of the day (work and business)." However, need should determine the advisability of having the course. If there is one woman in your ward who needs help, there is no question but that the class should be held. Raising Funds For New Chapels: Help the bishops all you can, but it is not the ward Relief Society president's responsibility to raise funds for new chapels. Mormon Handicraft: Mormon Handicraft sales have increased at least one-third this year. We appreciate the cooperation of the local sisters as well as the fine support of the advisory committee. Articles received have been of higher standard —fewer have been returned. We still need inexpensive articles but well made and attractive. We are still overstocked with some articles, so please write to us before the women go to the expense of making expensive things, such as bedspreads, and ascertain whether or not there is apt to be a sale for these articles. Membership dues are from January to January and are $1 a year for the ward or for an individual membership of anyone not a member of the Relief Society. Please check up and see if any of your women are depending upon the ward to take a membership. Literature Course: Due to present international trouble, it has been deemed advisable to change the third book in the Literature course. A new book will be substituted for the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse. While the Four Horsemen is a great novel, presenting a vivid picture of the horrors of war, we believe that a more cheerful book should be used. Refreshments on Work and Business Day: We have found that some wards are going rather to the extreme in serving refreshments on Work and Business day. Serve light refreshments occasionally; they make for sociability, and Work and Business day is the social day in Relief Society, but do not make this a burden. Visiting Teachers: The following new ruling has been made: When a reorganization of Relief Society takes place in the ward, all visiting teachers are to be released when the president is released. In many wards the great number of inactive visiting teachers has become a burden. In reorganizing the visiting teachers, do not overlook any sister who has rendered good service. Be prayerful about making your new selections. In some way, try to honor those who have given faithful service over a long period of years. The question has been asked: Should non-members of the Church serve as visiting teachers? Generally speaking, we say no. There is, of course, an occasional exception. For example, in the mission field where
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 775
they are greatly handicapped for workers, we may find a woman who is genuinely converted but for some good reason has not yet joined the Church. This sister might reasonably be used. But in our wards, let us use Latter-day Saint women who understand the principles of the Gospel to bear the Relief Society message to the homes. We request that visiting teachers be not asked to sell books or tickets for any organization or cause, including Relief Society. We do not want them to act as Magazine agents when making their regular visits. We also request that they be not used as an advertising medium for any cause, unless it be some special Relief Society activity. The teachers may carry such an announcement, but do not have them go as solicitors. Visiting teachers are to go with a spiritual message for the purpose of uplifting the family.
First General Session
RELIEF SOCIETY WELFARE WORK By Counselor Amy Brown Lyman
IT is interesting as well as inspirational for us to look back and recount the many achievements of Relief Society women of the past in the field of human welfare, and we love to do this. But it is equally interesting as well as gratifying to observe the fine work being done by Relief Society women of today in this same field. — The General Board appreciates your interest in the Church Welfare Program with which we are cooperating and to which we are devoted, and we commend you dear sisters for your efforts in this great undertaking—for the hours and days you have given to the cause. We appreciate also your ready attention to cases of need in your own wards. In all of our welfare work I am sure we are keeping in mind our ideal of helping people to help themselves and of trying to provide opportunity for them to do this. We appreciate your work in the interest of health and maternity welfare; in the general and special clinics you are aiding, and in the follow-up work you are doing in connection with them. We know that through your faithful efforts many children have been able to enter school this fall physically fit. But we are wondering if all the defects discovered were looked after or corrected. We are wondering if there are children in your communities who still have diseased tonsils and bad teeth, eyes that need glasses, ears that need attention, with apparently no one able to do anything about it. And what about malnutrition? We are hoping that our special nutrition work for this year will bear good fruit in this direction. We are mindful of the fact that last year you spent 33,000 days in volunteer nursing of the sick, and that you made 208,000 comforting and helpful visits to the sick, home-
776 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE
bound and handicapped. Also, that the visiting teachers made over one million friendly family visits. We appreciate your interest and activity in the campaign of the Church for the non-use of liquor and tobacco and thus for the protection of our children from these devastating poisons. Education and prevention in this matter, as you know, are especially important. The first cigarette is, for the youth, the easiest to refuse; the first drink, the easiest to pass up. When once a young person becomes a cigarette addict, an alcoholic or a drug addict, you who have had experience in case work know that you have a real problem and a heartbreaking situation. It is gratifying to know that we are united in our stand for total abstinence in these things. In Utah, California and probably in many other states, the schools have a definite program for teaching the effects of alcohol, tobacco and other narcotic drugs. Let us find out what these programs are and support them. Let us ask what each of our schools is doing in this respect. Dr. Skidmore, State Superintendent of Public Instruction in Utah, says: "The responsibility of carrying on this particular program for the good of our young people rests largely with the school executives but can not be successful unless it has the backing of communities, churches, all public-spirited organizations and the best citizens of the State." I recently read a stimulating article by Charles Longacre, Secretary of the American Temperance Association, on the subject, "Who Has A Right To Drink?" Riding on a railroad train recently was a group of men discussing the futility of laws restricting the right to drink intoxicating liquor. The idea prevailed that all men have a right to drink, the same as the right to eat; that to attempt to regulate drinking is an interference with a man's personal liberties. The conversation was interrupted by a passenger who drew near the group and asked this question, "Do you believe that the engineer and the train crew that operate this train should enjoy the liberty to drink intoxicating beverages?" The unanimous reply was, "No". He then asked why these should be discriminated against and denied this right and this freedom. The verdict was that the law should require these men to be sober so as not to endanger the lives of passengers on the train. Then there was a question about air pilots, with the same conclusion. It was then computed that there are 60,000 railroad engineers in the United States, all of whom should not be allowed this freedom and right. It was also computed that besides the 60,000 railroad engineers, there are about 35,000,000 licensed automobile engineers who are entrusted with high-powered gasoline engines on the public highways, where there are no rails, no guards and no signals. The question was asked, "Is it not necessary that these latter should be required to be sober as well as the railroad engineers?" Again the answer was, "Yes". So we might go on, says the author, and ask about drunken pedestrians walking in front of the automobiles and causing accidents, and about the parents of in-
RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 777
nocent little children who dethrone their reason and impair their good judgment by the use of intoxicating liquor. Personal liberty surely cannot in justice infringe upon the rightful liberty and freedom of others. Even "wets" are agreed that the sale of adulterated foods that are injurious to health should be prohibited as well as that dangerous drugs and firearms should be restricted. The author then asks, "Who has a right to drink?" In the last paragraph of his article he sums up as follows: "Who has a right to drink? Do I as a prospective father or you as a prospective mother have a right to drink alcoholic beverages, or use cocaine or marihuana when science tells me that my offspring will have to suffer the blight and curse of both mental and physical defects for it?... No father has a right to come home staggering and jabbering and cursing and abusing his wife and children because of drink. No mother has a right to bring shame and disgrace and a handicap upon her offspring because of drink. No son or daughter has a right to bring reproach and dishonor and ingratitude upon an upright and respectable father and mother because of drink. No citizen has a right to make a pauper out of himself, to be supported by society because of drink. Any nation that debauches and corrupts its youth through the curse of drink destroys its own future and commits national suicide." WE appreciate your interest in homemaking and in the building up of stable family life. We are a family agency. We believe in the family. We have faith in the family. We feel that the most vital concern of society should be the cultivation and conservation of the family and its restoration and rehabilitation where necessary. In recent years the family has been the subject of much discussion and criticism. Critics representing the most radical group contend that the maintenance of family life is surely threatened. It is most heartening to learn, from a survey made recently at the University of Minnesota, of the fine ideals held by many young people today. A long questionnaire was sent out to 1600 Minnesota alumni, asking about the things they thought most important and most desirable. The first five choices of things the men most wanted were: A happy married life, financial success, security for old age, a comfortable standard of living, and making a good home. The first five things women most wanted were: A happy married life, a comfortable standard of living, making a good home, children they could be proud of, and travel. It will be noted that the first choice of both men and women was a happy married life, and the fifth choice of the men and the third of the women was "making a good home". This is surely encouraging in this day of easy divorce. We commend Relief Society women for their devotion to the Gospel and its teachings. In this day of world confusion, we are challenged as are all other Christian groups to preserve and maintain the ethical, moral and religious standards and ideals set up by the Master. Let us dedicate ourselves to these ideals. It is evident that there is 778 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE need to work not only for economic recovery and for health, but also for moral and spiritual recovery—for moral and spiritual rearmament. The guiding power of religion and spirituality is desperately needed in the world today. May this be our first interest is my earnest prayer. A ae Second General Session ADDRESS By Mrs. Vincent Hilles Ober President, National Federation of Music Clubs THE National Federation of Music Clubs is complimented in having a place on the program of the Relief Society Conference. We are proud, with you, of the Singing Mothers. The National Federation of Music Clubs is better and stronger because of the membership maintained in it by the Singing Mothers of the Relief Society. America's foundations were laid 332 years ago—quite recently in contrast to those of Europe, and along very different lines. In a country which has carried forward the greatest and the most successful experiment in democracy which the world has known to date, it is important to preserve our freedom of musical expression along with our freedom of speech and religion. The music of the United States should be a democratic music, and music should be used as a means of building and msuring the freedom of American institutions. Through music we can do much to integrate nationalities within our country, working toward the ideal of developing life so that it will include a pattern of peace, of brotherhood, of harmony and understanding, of sympathy, of nobleness with reference to humanity as our keynote. Music has a greater mission than to merely create a friendly reaction among individuals, or furnish entertainment; it can be a great influence for good in the world, because people who are engaged in cultural development have no time for evil planning. In these days of misunderstanding and friction, we pray for the peaceful influence of the gospel of music, that nations and neighbors may be interpreted to each other. Weare not a singing nation. We would be a more confident nation if we sang together. The organization which I represent, the National Federation of Music Clubs, has functioned for over forty-one years in making Ametica more musical. Our members—men and women, boys and gitls—in their club life have accomplished a record of which we are. Proud. We work with children, and last year we had over eight thousand participate in our contests. We support young artists, giving them engagements. We inspire the composer and recognize compositions of value. We create scholarship funds for the underprivileged, talented RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 779 child. In 47 countries, through our international music clubs, the compositions of American composers have been presented. We have established a MacDowell Fellowship for the use of the American composer. We are collecting music and sending it to stricken China. We are going to a conference called by the Secretary of State in the interest of maintaining happy and friendly relations between the Americas. We know of the interpretative powers of music between nations; we are at this time emphasizing sending music abroad. Last week we sent a large supply of music to Belgium, Sweden and Scotland. May our foundations in the United States be strengthened by a high purpose for the support of all things good! ADDRESS; By President Louise Y. Robison N the early part of this year it was my privilege to attend a conference held in the White House. I wish you might have the thrill which came to me the day I spent there. It was not the beautiful building, it was not even the thought that presidents or officers of our government lived there, although I honor these men in their positions. It was something more than that; it was my country, and it stood for opportunity and the fine things of life which it gives to us just to the extent that we are prepared to receive them. I was a bit early for the conference, possibly twenty minutes before the opening of the meeting. I was so glad that I had a few minutes to think, and I thanked God that I could say, "This is my country," and it is my country because my parents accepted the gospel of Jesus Christ and came to this land. My parents were English-born. I was never more thankful for them, that they were the type who heard the voice of the Shepherd through His servants when he called them to gather to this land, described by the prophets in the Book of Mormon as a land choice above all other lands. There were representatives from Alaska, Hawaii, Porto Rico, as well as from every state in the Union except two in attendance at the conference. It was interesting to sec how earnestly the subject of character education for our children was approached and how sincerely ways and means of accomplishing this were sought. I was interested in the address of Mr. Homer Folks. I will read just a bit of his address to let you see, as I do now, the possibility of every little child, whether it be your child or another person's, if properly cared for. Sister Amy W., Evans, a former member of our General Board, used to say that good social work, good community service, means that the community gives to every child the same attention that one would want given to his own child. The following paragraph from Homer Folks implies the wonderful opportunities there are for children. He said: "In planning for this 1939 conference, we have been looking ahead, 780 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE not to 1940, but to 1980 or thereabouts. Somewhere within these United States, within the past few years, was born a child who will be elected in 1980 to the most responsible office in the world, whose incumbent lives here. We cannot guess his name or whereabouts. He may come from any place and from any social or economic group. He may now be in the home of one of the soft-coal miners, or in the family of a sharecropper, or quite possibly in the home of one of the unemployed, or in a family migrating from the Dust Bowl, or in a college professor's family, or he may be surrounded with every facility, convenience, and protection which money can buy. Very likely his home is on a farm. Even Dr. Gallup with his poll can give us no light on this problem." Children born in any of these situations can become leaders in this great country of ours. Mr. Folks later said that even though a child does not become President, there are hundreds of governors, mayors and lawmakers needed. In our Church think of the number of bishops, stake presidents and apostles needed, as well as the great office of president of the Church. What wonderful opportunities there are for children! But there are other things that must also be given them. Of course, attention was called to their need for good homes, food and medical help, but a fine Catholic Priest said, "Character, more than brains and brawn, is the essential for successful living and for an ordered society. To build character, youth must be taught the art of right thinking and the science of self-control." Speaking further, he said: "Man or child cannot do without absolutes; namely, the existence of God, the eternal and immutable principles of tight and wrong, and the inherent dignity of man." WHEN I heard these things, of course my mind turned to the Relief Society. What is Relief Society doing to uphold these standards and meet these needs? In listening to Sister Lyman and Sister Barker as they told of the real work we are doing, I realized that we have a program that will take care of every one of these needs. Statistics given me by a school nurse from a community within one hundred miles of Salt Lake City reveal that out of 476 examinations of sixth grade children, which means children about eleven years old who have their permanent teeth, only 60 children's teeth were in good condition. Now, much depends upon Relief Society. We have the means, we have the provisions for caring for these things. No matter how fine the spirit of a child or how hard he tries, he is handicapped when grown to manhood if he has a weak body. So we must build up the bodies of children and also direct them so they will live in accordance with the principles that have been given us. The thing that pleases me in contemplating all of this is that we were told to do these things by a prophet of God, a man whom God the Father and His Son Jesus Christ spoke to and told of the needs of the people not only a hundred years ago, but right today. Sisters of the Relief Society, see where you can put these things into practice. It was the opinion of the RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 781 conference held in the White House that the home, the school and the church are responsible for those things which they deemed even more essential than material things —the emotional and religious training that will result in good characters. I pray my Heavenly Father that He will bless you wonderful women, that He will go with you to your homes and to your groups, and that you will have the spirit which we have had in this conference. Yesterday was marvelous; there were so many splertdid instructions—read them in your Magazine. I think a very interesting thing is revealed in the life of the Savior, the Son of God. He had power to call legions to His command, but when that terrible hour came and He knew He had to pass through a terrible ordeal, the Bible tells us in Matthew that He went to Gethsemane with His disciples and He was sorrowful, and He said to his friends Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, "Tarry ye here, and watch with me." He was sorrowful unto death, and while He prayed they slept, and when He came to them, He said, "What, could ye not watch with me one hour?" I wonder if there is any one here who does not need the human touch, who does not, through the Relief Society, have the opportunity of watching the one hour with those who are bearing heavy burdens! Look after those who have heavy burdens. You have been given that privilege, you can comfort and bless souls. May God help you that you may see how to do it, and may you have His spirit to lead you I humbly ask in the name of Jesus Christ, Amen. SAUL, SAUL, WHY PERSECUTEST THOU ME?" — Saul's zeal and ability made him the scourge of the early Christians. He went from house to house ferreting out men and women who were members of the accursed society that proclaimed allegiance to Jesus, the arisen Messiah. Saul must have satisfied himself in time that the threat of a flourishing Christian community in Jerusalem was past, for we next find him seeking another field of labor. "And Saul, yet breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord, went unto the high priest, and desired of him. Letters to Damascus, to the synagogues, that if he found any of this Way, whether they were men or women, he might bring them bound unto Jerusalem." (Acts 9:1, 2.) We shall have to admit one thing about the Changed Life Saul—he was thorough. Nothing short of complete extermination of the early church satisfied him. The unusual quality of Saul's intellect and training shows up plainly even in his persecution activities. But the Lord took a hand. A vigorous, sincere, well-disciplined Pharisee, if rightly taught, could do just as much good in the service of the Church, as he could evil under the influence of a mistaken Jewish philosophy. Let us not be misled. Saul was no ordinary Pharisee. He had undoubtedly led a clean, wholesome life which, judging from certain statements of Christ in the Gospels, could not be said of some Pharisees. Furthermore, he had the special qualities necessary to make a successful apostle. Otherwise, the Master would never have chosen him for the important service he had in mind. We truly believe that Saul in all of his persecutions and drivings of the Christians did so with a firm conviction that he was in God's service. (I Timothy 1:12, 13.) He was no hypocrite. Shortly before reaching Damascus, Saul had his famous vision. "And suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven; and he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why per- RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 783 secutest thou me?" We need not argue, as some have done, over the details of this vision and attempt to wrest from the Scriptures more than they plainly tell us. (Acts 9:3-9; 22:6-11; 26:12-18; I Cor. 15:8.) Suffice it to say that Saul knew, better than it was possible for mortal man to express, that Jesus was the Christ. He was henceforth to be in the service of the Master. SAUL REVERSES HIMSELF. We can only imagine what it must have meant to a man of Saul's training and temperament to suddenly find that the hated Jesus of Nazareth, whose humble followers he had been persecuting, was in reality the Messiah for whose coming the Jews were all looking. The greater the intelligence and training of a man under such circumstances, the greater the shock—and Saul was highly intelligent. When he could find words he said, "Who art thou, Lord?" The Lord said, "I am Jesus, whom thou persecutest. But rise, and stand upon thy feet; for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen, and of those things in the which I will appear unto thee; delivering thee from the people, and from the Gentiles, unto whom I now send thee, to open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me. Go into the city, and it shall be told thee what thou must do." (See Acts 26:16-18; 9:5, 6.) It will be noted that Saul mentions not one word of reproach from the Savior. He was taken, physically blind, but spiritually very much awake, to Damascus where he was left at the house of one Judas, who was probably expecting him. (Acts 9:11.) Saul's three days of blindness roughly correspond in effect to the repetition of visions experienced by the Prophet Joseph Smith—his affliction gave him a good opportunity for mental readjustment and impressed the teachings he had received more firmly upon his mind. His theology, like Job, was on the ash heap, but out of it a new one, incomparably greater, was to arise. Saul's remarkable training in the Scriptures enabled him to understand quickly the teachings of Christ. Soon the whole panorama of Christian philosophy would be spread out before his quick mentality. After Ananias had healed Saul (Acts 9:10-19) the latter began to preach of Christ as zealously as he had formerly persecuted him. He did so well that soon the Jews sought to put him to death. (Acts 9:20-25.) This change on Saul's part we may call the Great Reversal. It is probably the greatest in history and has had greatest effects. A JEWISH THEOLOGIAN LEARNS CHRISTIANITY. One gets the impression from reading Acts 9:26-30 that Saul, immediately after escaping his enemies in Damascus, set out for Jerusalem and on arriving there conferred with the apostles. In the letter to the Galatians (1:16-19) we get a different understanding of what happened. "I immediately conferred not with flesh and blood; neither went I up to Jerusalem to those which were apostles before me, but I went away into Arabia, and returned again unto Da- 784 - NOVEMBER, RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE mascus. Then, after three years, I went up to Jerusalem to see Peter, and abode with him fifteen days. But other of the apostles saw I none, save James, the Lord's brother." We do not know what part of Arabia Saul departed to, whether Sinai in the south, or elsewhere. He found quiet places where he could meditate and be taught by the spirit of revelation. In his letter to the Galatians, Saul emphasizes the fact that he did not receive the Gospel from man. "Nor was I taught it, but I received it through revelation of Jesus Christ." (Galatians 1:12.) It is perfectly possible that Saul, like Moses, John the Baptist, and even the Christ, learned many or most of the principles he was to teach by revelation while in Arabia. Because of the fact that he was to be a special emissary to the Gentiles he no doubt received instructions pertaining to that calling. We should much like to know what passed between Peter and Saul during the latter's visit to Jerusalem. It is probable that Peter told Saul first hand his experiences in the service of the Master and received in exchange the younger man's story of his unusual revelation. The visit of the future Apostle of the Gentiles to Jerusalem was not devoid of unpleasant experiences. The disciples still remembered his former persecutions and were afraid of him until Barnabas reassured them. (Acts 9:26, 27.) While in Jerusalem Saul preached boldly and soon was forced to flee to Tarsus via Caesarea. (Acts 9:28-30.) Saul seems to have worked in Syria and Cilicia for a long time, apparently fourteen years. (Galatians 1:21; 2:1.) During this period he received remarkable revelations that set him apart as one of God's great men. (See II Corinthians 12:1-4.) All of these experiences prepared Saul for the wider fields of missionary service that were yet to come. SAUL APPROVED FOR THE WORK. It is not to be inferred by this topic heading that Saul had not already been preaching. But his most vital and lasting contribution to Christianity was yet to come. The young Church of Christ had not yet formally declared its approval of a mission to the Gentiles. And work among the Gentiles was destined to be Saul's special work and joy. One of the many points showing the Acts to be an inspired book is that Peter, not Saul, formally opens the mission to the Gentiles. (Acts 10, 11.) That is as it should be for, according to the order of the Priesthood, it was Peter's prerogative to receive the revelation pertaining to and give the orders to set in motion any momentous undertaking. True enough, Saul had apparently been preaching: to the Gentiles, but not officially. (Galatians 2:2.) According to Acts 11:19-30 a thriving branch of the Church had been built up at Antioch. A number of "Greeks," or Gentiles, had also believed and "turned to the Lord". The report of them created great interest in Jerusalem, and Barnabas was sent to investigate. He sought out Saul, and both of them worked a year in Antioch with great success. At the time of the great famine, Barnabas and Saul were entrusted with relief funds for the brethren at Jerusalem. (See Acts 11:27-30.) It is probable that this visit is the one referred to in Gal. RELIEF SOCIETY MAGAZINE, NOVEMBER - 785 2:1, 2. "Then, fourteen years after, I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, and took Titus with me, also. And I went up by revelation, and communicated unto them that Gospel which I preach among the Gentiles." Apparently the time was at hand for Saul to begin his formal mission to the Gentiles, and the Lord wanted him to explain his views and calling to the heads of the Church. In fact, Saul says that he had been intrusted "with the gospel of the Uncircumcision, as Peter was with that of the Circumcision." (Gal. 2:7.) The Church Authorities then gave Saul and Barnabas "right hands of fellowship" that they should go to the Gentiles. (Gal. 2:9.)
